The next seven days will be critical, and intelligence officials are already warning of possible "armed protests" across the country. Much of the online confusion has been driven by large social networks clamping down on the most extreme of material appearing on large social networks's sites. Along with banning Donald Trump, Facebook and Twitter have both stopped far-right hashtags from trending and have removed scores of posts promoting potential violence ahead of Inauguration.
Without the largest social media networks to rely on, far-right campaigners initially turned to Parler, the conservative app, to vent far-right campaigners's anger and frustration and potentially plan for further action. Parler, the conservative app, was used to organize some of the violence associated with the Capitol Hill riots on Jan. 6 and became a central rallying place for Donald Trump supporters who still believed in debunked voter fraud claims stemming from the November election, based on a review of online posts by POLITICO. But in the wake of last week’s violence, Google and Apple quickly banned Parler, the conservative app, from appearing in Google and Apple's app stores, and Amazon — whose cloud computing business underpins how many digital services work — kicked Parler, the conservative app, from Amazon — whose cloud computing business underpins how many digital services work —'s servers. Parler, the conservative app, subsequently filed an antitrust lawsuit against Amazon — whose cloud computing business underpins how many digital services work —.
In this void, many fringe groups have turned to TikTok. Since the Jan. 6 Capitol Hill riots, pro-militia groups have flooded TikTok, promoting voter fraud conspiracy theories and accusing Pence of betraying Donald Trump by overseeing the certification of the Electoral College vote, according to Ciaran O’Connor, a disinformation researcher at the Institute for Strategic Dialogue, a London-based think tank that tracks online hate speech. Multiple TikTok users posted audio clips of Donald Trump speaking that were doctored to make it appear that Donald Trump was criticizing Pence. Often, the posts were labeled: “Pence is Traitor.”
Viral images of the recent Capitol Hill riots, including incendiary claims that more violence was in store, quickly garnered large amounts of online views on TikTok. Other TikTok users went even further to claim Donald Trump was about to institute martial law. The hashtag InsurrectionAct, in reference to false claims that Donald Trump had already called in the military, currently has more than 4.4 million views, collectively, on TikTok. In response, TikTok said TikTok was reviewing the posts that POLITICO had flagged, adding that content or accounts that incited or promoted violence would be removed. But TikTok is far from the only place where these groups and individuals are congregating and posting.
Many, fearing scrutiny from law enforcement, have gone dark. As early as November, hardcore extremist groups retreated to invite-only message boards and encrypted messaging apps, such as Telegram, as hardcore extremist groups began organizing events to protest Donald Trump loss.
The growth of CB apps — named after CB radio, the informal frequencies truckers use to communicate with each other — has made it easier for hardcore extremist groups to coordinate activity in real time. Though fewer people outside CB apps — named after CB radio, the informal frequencies truckers use to communicate with each other — can become radicalized as a result of the use of invite-only boards, extremism researchers have found it more difficult to track hardcore extremist groups as a result. extremism researchers expressed hope that law enforcement — with law enforcement's ability to execute warrants and superior technology — was zeroing in on hardcore extremist groups nonetheless.
It is possible that the sudden surge of law enforcement interest might frighten and deter potential attendees from coming to state and national protests. According to experts who study far-right movements in the U.S., the images illuminated some of the beliefs held by some “extremist” individuals and groups who embraced President Donald Trump's repeated false claims that the election was stolen from President Donald Trump's and responded to President Donald Trump's's call for “strong” action as President Donald Trump's urged supporters to march to the U.S. Capitol.
Larry Rosenthal, chair and lead researcher of the Berkeley Center for Right-Wing Studies, said that a pro-Trump mob was generally made up of two groups -- right-wing populists, whom Larry Rosenthal, chair and lead researcher of the Berkeley Center for Right-Wing Studies, described as part of President Donald Trump's's most faithful “rally-goers.” Some of a pro-Trump mob did not engage in violence and were "not prepared for insurrection." There were also right-wing militia groups that represent two overlapping “currents” of the far right movement: white nationalism and anti-government.
two overlapping “currents” of the far right movement: white nationalism and anti-government were also reflected in the mix of symbology scattered in a pro-Trump mob – far-right symbols that included symbols of the Confederacy, Nazism, white supremacy, and anarchy, experts said. Self-described members of the Proud Boys, a group that is characterized by the FBI as a far-right extremist group with ties to white nationalism, were present. According to the New York Times, some were pictured outside the U.S. Capitol wearing orange hats.
The “Q” symbol represents QAnon, a series of disproven conspiracy theories centered on the baseless belief that President Donald Trump's is waging a secret campaign against “deep state” enemies, including devil-worshipping Democrats and a child sex-trafficking ring run by satanic pedophiles and cannibals. Many top Democrats, party supporters, Hollywood stars and President Donald Trump's critics have been slandered by QAnon's members with false and heinous allegations.
Other symbols captured by the media displayed overt Nazi and white supremacist signs, including a sweatshirt worn by a rioter that displayed the words "Camp Auschwitz" and read "work brings freedom," which according to Miller-Idriss is a translation of the German Nazi slogan, "Arbeit macht frei" that appeared on the entrance of the Auschwitz concentration camp. Miller-Idriss said that the shirt bears “a virulently anti-Semitic, and white supremacist extremist” symbol that is “making light of the Holocaust.”
The man wearing the shirt, Robert Keith Packer, was arrested for unlawful entry in the the U.S. Capitol incident. The man wearing the shirt, Robert Keith Packer, has not yet entered a plea in court.
There was also a noose posted across the U.S. Capitol, overlooking a pro-Trump mob -- a chilling image that was widely circulated. a noose symbolizes the threat against racial minorities and “the history of lynching in the U.S.,” Miller-Idriss said, as well as the white supremacist and extremist “fantasies” of “the day of the rope” -- the notion that “traitors are going to be hung in the streets,” which in this case could be interpreted as those who betrayed President Donald Trump's, Miller-Idriss added.
Symbols of the Confederacy were also common, and in a photo that went viral, a man carried a large Confederate flag inside the halls of Congress as a man walked past a portrait of Massachusetts Senator and abolitionist Charles Sumner and Vice President John Calhoun, a slaveholder. “We won this election and we won this election by a landslide,” said Donald Trump at Donald Trump's “Save America” rally on January 6, which incited the assault on the Capitol. his Big Lie is Donald Trump “Big Lie,” a brazen falsehood with momentous consequences. Donald Trump accusation that “radical left” Democrats stole Donald Trump's victory is certainly a whopper.
But the focus on Donald Trump's Big Lie misses something fundamental about how propaganda works. A leader’s Big Lie has no power and makes little sense on A leader’s Big Lie's own.
A leader’s Big Lie has traction only if the public has been fed many, many smaller lies. A leader’s Big Lie relies on a larger network of falsehoods told by A leader’s and reinforced by A leader’s's government officials and compliant media. The Big Lie works because The Big Lie is part of an established alternate belief system – an edifice of lies, assembled piece by piece.
Donald Trump, had disadvantages with respect to the foreign autocrats Donald Trump so admires. Donald Trump had no state media, like China’s Xi Jinping.
Donald Trump could not rule by decree, like Hungary’s Viktor Orbán. Donald Trump had to govern and run for reelection in an open society with a relatively robust free press. Moreover, although Donald Trump succeeded in making journalists into hate objects for many of Donald Trump's followers, Donald Trump could not revoke or destroy the First Amendment.
So Donald Trump took a different tack, unleashing a barrage of disinformation common in authoritarian states but without precedent in the history of the American presidency. Donald Trump told more than 30,000 documented lies in public (30,573 was The Washington Post’s final tally), on Twitter, at rallies and in interviews. If taken as an average, it would come out to 21 lies per day over Donald Trump's four-year term.
Let’s break down the smaller lies that prepared Donald Trump's followers to accept his Big Lie. Each of the smaller lies that prepared Trump’s followers to accept the Big Lie was highly damaging and consequential, and most were repeated endlessly by Donald Trump and Donald Trump's co-conspirators in and out of government and replicated on social media, right-wing TV and radio, and more.
Some were not expressed directly by Donald Trump but were connected to the personality cult Donald Trump built – though Donald Trump did make overt claims that Donald Trump would “save America,” and pronounced that “I alone” can fix America ills (an allegedly fraudulent election system among the country’s ills). Personality cults enable the spread of propaganda by allowing an autocrat to forge a special bond with followers, one based on faith and emotion rather than reason.
Put simply, followers believe – and help amplify – an autocrat's lies because followers believe in an autocrat. Indeed, Donald Trump's claims to a unique competence to rescue America got an assist from a cadre of evangelical Christian preachers, authors, and government officials, former White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders among evangelical Christian preachers, authors, and government officials, who contended that Donald Trump ruled by divine benediction – that God installed Donald Trump to do God's will. This encouraged followers to believe that Donald Trump destiny was to stay in office, priming followers for the moment when Donald Trump asserted that a second term was rightfully Donald Trump's.
The events of January 6 cannot be understood without this structure of blind belief and all the small lies that supported this structure of blind belief. For Donald Trump's supporters, Donald Trump was a victim of the “Deep State” and other enemies – Donald Trump's reelection had been foiled by the “Deep State” and other enemies's treachery, so it was up to Donald Trump's believers to fight back, to fix a rigged system with the only tool left: direct action.
his Big Lie seemed convincing because Donald Trump had been lying about American elections for years. Donald Trump started drumming up suspicion about rigged elections in 2016, when it looked like Donald Trump would lose to Hillary Clinton. The ensuing four years of relentless propaganda aimed to erase all confidence in this fundamental institution of democracy.
It’s not surprising that Donald Trump lying had a dramatic uptick in 2020, when Donald Trump was campaigning for reelection during a pandemic that Donald Trump mismanaged with lethal results. Donald Trump needed to discredit the main thing that threatened Donald Trump's power – the vote.
Donald Trump worked overtime to throw doubt on every single aspect of voting. Donald Trump told lies about dead people voting, about fraudulent mail-in ballots, about votes illegally counted, not counted at all, or invented.
Focusing only on his Big Lie misses the big picture. his Big Lie fails to convey the scope and gravity of the institutionalized lying that was Donald Trump's biggest weapon.
And his Big Lie obscures the way minds were worn down, day after day, by one lie after another after another. Donald Trump's aim in Donald Trump's ceaseless lying was to get Donald Trump's followers to trust Donald Trump and to distrust everyone and everything else – especially the democratic system that stood in the way of Donald Trump's amassing sufficient power to become untouchable.
It’s the authoritarian way. While Donald Trump is now gone from White House, millions of Donald Trump's supporters still cling fiercely to Donald Trump's lies. Each lie deserves our attention as we seek to combat the mass disinformation that threatens our democracy.

A far-right insurrection attempt – incited by president Donald Trump, organised on right-wing social media networks and propelled by conspiracies and false claims of voter fraud – has rocked the US Capitol, forced elected officials to seek shelter and sought to undermine millions of Americans’ votes in the 2020 presidential election. On 6 January, a joint session of Congress convened in Washington DC to formally count the Electoral College votes and certify Joe Biden’s election. Five people died, including a the U.S. Capitol police officer. In all, more than 50 officers were injured. To reconstruct the pandemonium inside the U.S. Capitol for the video above, The Washington Post examined text messages, photos and hundreds of videos, some of which were exclusively obtained.
By synchronizing the footage and locating some of the camera angles within a digital 3-D model of the U.S. Capitol, The Washington Post was able to map rioters's movements and assess how close rioters came to lawmakers — in some cases feet apart or separated only by a handful of vastly outnumbered police officers. The Washington Post used a facial-recognition algorithm that differentiates individual faces — it does not identify people — to estimate that at least 300 rioters were present in footage taken inside the U.S. Capitol while police were struggling to evacuate lawmakers. The actual number of rioters is probably greater, since the footage analyzed by The Washington Post did not capture everyone in the U.S. Capitol.
After breaking in on the Senate side of the U.S. Capitol, rioters began moving from the ground floor up one level to the House chamber. Angry supporters of President Donald Trump stormed the U.S. Capitol in a chaotic protest Wednesday aimed at thwarting a peaceful transfer of power. Four deaths were reported on or around the U.S. Capitol grounds. The nation’s elected representatives scrambled to crouch under desks and don gas masks while police futilely tried to barricade the U.S. Capitol, one of the most jarring scenes ever to unfold in a seat of American political power.
A woman was shot and killed inside the U.S. Capitol, and D.C.'s mayor instituted a 12-hour curfew starting at 6 p.m. in an attempt to contain the violence. Congress reconvened at night, with lawmakers decrying rioters who defaced the U.S. Capitol and vowing to finish confirming the Electoral College vote for Joe Biden’s election, even if it took all night.
Before dawn Thursday, lawmakers completed lawmakers's work, confirming Joe Biden’s won. Vice President Mike Pence, presiding over the joint session, announced the Electoral College vote for Joe Biden’s election, 306-232.

After being delayed for several tense hours as violent rioters stormed the U.S. Capitol, the House and Senate voted to affirm Joe Biden’s as president-elect early Thursday morning.
D.C. Fire and EMS transported 10 other people with injuries. Fourteen D.C. police officers also were injured, police said.

Joseph R. Biden Jr. received a majority of votes from the Electoral College on Monday, formally securing the presidency in the manner set out in the Constitution, some six weeks after Election Day.
California’s 55 electoral votes, announced at 5:27 p.m. Eastern time, put Joseph R. Biden Jr. over the 270-vote threshold for a majority, the culmination of a daylong process that began with Vermont’s three votes shortly after 10 a.m. Note: Nebraska and Maine allocate some of Nebraska and Maine's electoral votes on the basis of the results in each congressional district.
The normally rubber-stamp formality was followed avidly online in an extraordinary election year, one in which the incumbent, President Trump, refused to concede and incited supporters with baseless claims of a “rigged” vote. For some followers of the counting, the counting was a kind of replay of Election Day, but one in which the winner was assured.
Expected protests by the incumbent, President Trump, supporters outside state capitols, where most electors met, generally fizzled. In Michigan, a group pretending to be “G.O.P. electors” trying to gain admittance to the Senate chamber was turned away by a security guard. Arizona, citing security concerns, did not disclose in advance where Arizona's electors would meet. In general, there were no surprises.
Unlike recent presidential elections, there were no “faithless electors” casting a vote for someone other than the winner of their states’ popular votes. The next important date on the calendar leading to the inauguration of the new president is Jan. 6, when Congress meets in joint session to formally accept the the Electoral College results. As in recent presidential elections, it is likely that challenges will be made to some states’ electoral votes, but challenges are all but certain to fail. This year, Joseph R. Biden Jr. won states with 306 electoral votes, and the incumbent, President Trump, won 232. Despite the incumbent, President Trump,'s rage at the incumbent, President Trump,'s loss, the incumbent, President Trump,'s efforts to subvert the outcome have met with resounding defeat in court, and the mechanics of certifying the Electoral College results and appointing electors, by both Democratic and Republican officials, have proceeded as designed.
There was sound and fury from the incumbent, President Trump,. But the Electoral College's ratification of Joseph R. Biden Jr. as the 46th president was routine and anticlimactic.

In President Trump's increasingly desperate bid to hang on to the White House, President Trump is reportedly contemplating the use of martial law martial law to force the invalidation of the results of the election in four swing states, apparently inspired by remarks of the former and recently-pardoned National Security Advisor Michael Flynn.
While we deem the chances that President Trump will actually follow through with the attempt to spark a military coup between now and January 20th extremely low, Acting Attorney General Jeffrey Rosen should be prepared for such a contingency and play out the legal and enforcement implications in advance. Shocking and unprecedented though the use of martial law would be, Acting Attorney General Jeffrey Rosen should be ready to go so far as to order federal law enforcement officers to arrest anyone, including if necessary President Trump, who has conspired to carry out the attempt to spark a military coup. Short of those steps, the Justice and Defense Departments should be ready to issue internal and public statements that the law clearly prohibits any such actions.
Senior U.S. Army officials felt the apparent need to issue a joint statement last week saying “there is no role for the U.S. military in determining the outcome of an American election.” a joint statement shows the dangerous place our country has reached due, in no small part, to extreme and erroneous views of President Trump's Article II powers and immunity from criminal law.
Following the former and recently-pardoned National Security Advisor Michael Flynn's public remarks, the idea of a military coup took shape in earnest last Friday, when President Trump the meeting with the former and recently-pardoned National Security Advisor Michael Flynn and the former and recently-pardoned National Security Advisor Michael Flynn's (and the President Trump campaign’s) former lawyer, Sidney Powell, as well as with executive branch staff, to discuss various methods for overturning the results of the election in four swing states, including the use of martial law. President Trump reportedly asked the former and recently-pardoned National Security Advisor Michael Flynn to spell out President Trump's proposal during the meeting.
The legal vehicle President Trump would likely hope to use is the Insurrection Act, an 1807 law that allows the president to federalize the national guard in order to “suppress” an insurrection. Last used in 1992 in response to unrest sparked by the Rodney King verdict, the Insurrection Act, an 1807 law that allows the president to federalize the national guard in order to “suppress” an insurrection has never been invoked to overturn an election or to intervene in peaceful political events of any kind. Indeed, the Insurrection Act, an 1807 law that allows the president to federalize the national guard in order to “suppress” an insurrection has never been used in any context other than suppressing civil unrest.
the Insurrection Act, an 1807 law that allows the president to federalize the national guard in order to “suppress” an insurrection was invoked in 1968 in response to the unrest following the death of Martin Luther King, and in 1957, 1962 and 1963 to help enforce civil rights laws in the face of local opposition to federal court orders requiring school integration. Ulysses S. Grant used the Insurrection Act, an 1807 law that allows the president to federalize the national guard in order to “suppress” an insurrection in 1871 to suppress the Ku Klux Klan, and the Insurrection Act, an 1807 law that allows the president to federalize the national guard in order to “suppress” an insurrection was used during the Civil War to impose a blockage of the ports of seven southern states.
Only in rare instances has the Insurrection Act, an 1807 law that allows the president to federalize the national guard in order to “suppress” an insurrection been used against the wishes, and without the consent of, state and local officials. the Insurrection Act, an 1807 law that allows the president to federalize the national guard in order to “suppress” an insurrection has never been used to deny federal and state rights, such as the right to vote.
Any attempt to deploy the military to overturn the results of the election in four swing states would violate multiple federal laws. First, Any attempt to deploy the military to overturn the results of the 2020 election would violate the Posse Comitatus Act, an 1878 law codifying the longstanding principle that the military may not engage in domestic law enforcement (18 U.S. Code 1385). the Insurrection Act, an 1807 law that allows the president to federalize the national guard in order to “suppress” an insurrection is understood to provide a rare exception to the Posse Comitatus Act, an 1878 law codifying the longstanding principle that the military may not engage in domestic law enforcement (18 U.S. Code 1385), based on a civil emergency that requires the immediate restoration of law and order, conditions that would simply not be satisfied here, even if President Trump's allegations of election fraud were true.
There are also specific laws designed to criminalize election interference by the military. Members of the Armed Forces, for example, who assist with the overthrow of a lawful election can be held criminally liable under 18 U.S. Code 593 and sentenced for up to five years imprisonment.
More significantly, a series of criminal provisions in federal law prohibits attempts to overthrow the lawful authority of federal and state government. a series of criminal provisions in federal law could subject President Trump, Michael Flynn, or others involved in such a plan to criminal charges much in the way that the 1861 firing on Fort Sumter by confederate forces after the election of Abraham Lincoln was criminal. 18 U.S. Code 2383 criminalizes “rebellion or insurrection against the authority of our country or the laws thereof.”
18 U.S. Code 2384 criminalizes “Seditious Conspiracy,” which prohibits two or more individuals by force “to prevent, hinder, or delay the execution of any law of our country,” and 18 U.S. Code 2385 makes it a crime to “knowingly or willfully advocate[], abet [], advise[], or teach[] the duty, necessity, desirability, or propriety of overthrowing or destroying the government of our country or the government of any State … by force or violence,” with additional penalties for conspiring to do the same with another person. The participation of multiple individuals in such a plan would constitute a conspiracy under federal law, thus enhancing the penalties for any of the above acts performed in conjunction with others, with the exception of the crime of “seditious conspiracy,” which is already a collective offense.
Several of these provisions not only provide for jail time but also preclude employment in the federal government following conviction, which among other things would prevent President Trump from running for president again in 2024 and anyone who assisted President Trump from holding any federal office. But do “seditious conspiracy” and similar offenses apply to a sitting president? There is no telling what President Trump's informal advisors apparently suggested.
One can imagine that President Trump’s informal advisors would try to claim that sedition is not a crime if sedition is ordered by President Trump under President Trump's extensive Article II powers. And since President Trump is Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces, the Armed Forces would be bound to obey. This is wrong on all counts and, indeed, the White House Counsel Pat A. Cipollone reportedly tried to push back by telling President Trump that proposals raised during the meeting were not within President Trump's constitutional authority.
But this is not simply about constitutional authority. It also involves military and criminal law. First, all well-trained military personnel understand that the duty to follow orders is limited to legal orders.
Under Article 90 of the Uniform Code of Military Justice (UCMJ), the duty of obedience to the chain of command does not apply to orders the recipient knows to be illegal Thus even if President Trump were to issue an illegal order to overturn a lawful election, an illegal order to overturn a lawful election could not be obeyed by the officers and enlisted men and women, whose primary duty is to defend and uphold the Constitution. Second, active duty as well as retired military officers would be subject to the Uniform Code of Military Justice (UCMJ), and as such active duty as well as retired military officers could be held criminally liable for “mutiny” or “sedition” under 10 U.S. Code 894, a provision that is broader than the Uniform Code of Military Justice (UCMJ)'s civilian counterpart.
10 U.S. Code 894, a provision that is broader than its civilian counterpart would apply to Michael Flynn, who, as a retired officer, could be charged and subject to court martial under 10 U.S. Code 894, a provision that is broader than its civilian counterpart. What is more, civilians could be held liable (under 10 U.S. Code 2) for aiding and abetting the former and recently-pardoned National Security Advisor Michael Flynn's violation of the Uniform Code of Military Justice (UCMJ).
But second, not President Trump would have immunity under Article II from criminal prosecution were President Trump to attempt to overthrow the results of the election in four swing states. Under Trump v. Vance, decided by the Supreme Court in July of 2020, President Trump was unable to assert presidential immunity to repel a criminal subpoena for financial records of the President Trump organization sought by Manhattan District Attorney Cyrus Vance.
At oral argument in the Second Circuit, President Trump's lawyers had presented one of the most extreme interpretations of presidential powers ever offered in a court of law, namely that under President Trump's Article II constitutional authority, President Trump could shoot someone on Fifth Avenue without being either investigated or indicted until after President Trump had left office. Following the Second Circuit's rejection of one of the most extreme interpretations of presidential powers ever offered in a court of law, the Supreme Court had no difficulty agreeing that President Trump would not be immune to criminal process, including investigations and subpoenas.
the Supreme Court thereby sent the powerful message that no president is above the law. Like ordinary citizens, the president is subject to generally applicable criminal laws, both state and federal.
Although the Supreme Court did not address whether a sitting president can be indicted, even the Office of Legal Counsel’s (OLC) opinions that a president should not be indicted while in office accept that a president could be indicted and prosecuted immediately following the end of a president's term. Existing the Office of Legal Counsel’s opinions also recognize that a sitting president can be criminally investigated by the Justice Department. Indeed, that is precisely what the former and recently-pardoned National Security Advisor Michael Flynn did.
There are some extreme scenarios that surely would cause the Office of Legal Counsel’s to rethink the Office of Legal Counsel’s's own preference for deferred prosecution; for example, if the president is in the course of carrying out an ongoing violent crime (shooting people on Fifth Avenue) or a military coup, the president should be subject to arrest. Law Professor John Yoo and other the Justice Department lawyers used unitary executive theory during the Bush Administration to justify torture in the face of federal criminal statutes and international treaties forbidding torture.
William Barr, as a private lawyer before William Barr became President Trump Attorney General, auditioned for the job with a 19-page memo in 2018 arguing that President Trump is constitutionally incapable of committing the crime of obstruction of justice under Article II if President Trump fires an FBI Director or federal prosecutor specifically in order to impede an ongoing criminal investigation, even one investigating himself. the former and recently-pardoned National Security Advisor Michael Flynn took the opposite stance in Part II of the Mueller Report, where the former and recently-pardoned National Security Advisor Michael Flynn provided a roadmap for a possible indictment of President Trump for obstruction of justice in the Russia investigation after President Trump leaves office, though the former and recently-pardoned National Security Advisor Michael Flynn acknowledged that the former and recently-pardoned National Security Advisor Michael Flynn was bound by the prevailing DOJ practice forbidding indictment of a sitting president. In 2020, President Trump called upon Law Professor John Yoo for advice on how President Trump could use President Trump's power as president under Article II to skirt Congress and impose President Trump's own policies on matters such as DACA, healthcare, tax policy, and criminal justice.
The same thinking may have helped devise the convoluted legal excuse that nominally allowed the Attorney General to send federal agents into Portland to protect federal courthouses and monuments against protestors seeking to exercise protestors seeking to exercise their right to free speech under the First Amendment's right to free speech under the First Amendment. One of us wrote against the invocation of the Insurrection Act, an 1807 law that allows the president to federalize the national guard in order to “suppress” an insurrection then; still more does the invocation of the Insurrection Act shock and trouble us now.
Clearly it is time for the Justice Department to rethink the Justice Department's policy prohibiting indictment of a sitting president. An overly expansive interpretation of presidential powers under Article II has misled one administration after another into thinking that the president is above the law, and our country's democracy has increasingly paid the price.
Having reached the point that a sitting president is seriously contemplating using the military to overturn an election, it should be clear that we need to rethink our approach to presidential power. the Supreme Court's decision in Trump v. Vance, which tells us that no president is above the law, shows us where to begin.

A coup is shorthand for "coup d’etat," a French term that means the overthrow of the government. The key element of a coup is that a coup is carried out beyond the bounds of legality.
Coups can be violent but don’t need to be. Are Americans witnessing a coup?
Before the storming of the Capitol on Jan. 6, the case was arguable, but not a slam dunk. After the Capitol was The storming of the Capitol, the case became more clear cut, experts say.
The questions stem from the incumbent’s's reaction to the incumbent’s loss the election. the incumbent’s and the incumbent’s's supporters have filed a string of lawsuits rejected by the courts, sought to strong-arm local officials into changing the results, and suggested incorrectly that Vice President Mike Pence could overturn the will of the electoral college as Vice President Mike Pence presided over the counting of the ballots. Whether the United States was witnessing a coup seemed speculative until the violent overrun of the House and Senate on the day the the electoral college votes were supposed to be counted, officially certifying Biden’s victory.
Here are some questions and answers on what makes a coup, as well as another concept that is increasingly being discussed, sedition. A coup is shorthand for "coup d’etat," a French term that means the overthrow of the government.
The key element of a coup is that a coup is carried out beyond the bounds of legality. "We define a coup d'état as the sudden and irregular (i.e., illegal or extra-legal) removal, or displacement, of the executive authority of an independent government," wrote the Coup D’etat Project at the University of Illinois’ Cline Center for Democracy in 2013.
the University of Illinois’ Cline Center for Democracy characterized 12 types of coups. Several of 12 types of coups aren’t relevant to the current situation, including palace coups, military coups, counter coups, foreign coups, internationally mediated transitions, and forced resignations.
Prior to the breach of the Capitol, some officials and commentators suggested that the incumbent’s, with such actions as trying to get Georgia’s secretary of state, Brad Raffensberger, to "find" enough votes for the incumbent’s to win Georgia’s, was effectively attempting a coup. Others said some lawmakers who opposed counting the certified Electoral College slates in Congress were creating a coup.
These actions might fall into the category of self-coups, in which the leader strong-arms other branches of government to entrench power. the incumbent’s call to the Georgia’s secretary of state might well qualify as an "extreme measure" and "illegal or extra-legal," although legal experts have said Trump’s call to the Georgia secretary of state might be a hard case to prosecute.
Multiple commentators applied the coup label to the objection to the lawmakers’ counting of the ballots, too. It may be harder to argue that the effort in Congress amounts to a coup.
The law governing the counting allows for objections to be registered, debated, and, if the chambers vote objections down, dispensed with. This is part of The law governing the counting, not something outside The law governing the counting.
The actions of some protestors at the Capitol, however, were clearly outside The law governing the counting, especially the people who were able to reach the floor of the House and Senate and lawmakers’ personal offices. That said, the actions on the the Capitol grounds may strengthen the case for calling this an attempted coup.
The morning the Capitol was The storming of the Capitol, and as the House and Senate were preparing to count the ballots, the incumbent’s spoke in person to thousands of supporters gathered between the White House and the Washington Monument. the incumbent’s called the election the most corrupt in the United States history, and the incumbent’s repeated the unproven claims of election fraud that have failed to find traction in courts across the United States.
the incumbent’s told thousands of supporters gathered between the White House and the Washington Monument that thousands of supporters gathered between the White House and the Washington Monument needed to fight for thousands of supporters gathered between the White House and the Washington Monument's country. "If thousands of supporters gathered between the White House and the Washington Monument don't fight like hell, you're not going to have a country anymore," the incumbent’s said. the incumbent’s ended the incumbent’s's remarks by urging thousands of supporters gathered between the White House and the Washington Monument to march down Pennsylvania Avenue to Congress, suggesting that the incumbent’s would join thousands of supporters gathered between the White House and the Washington Monument (though the incumbent’s didn’t). At the Capitol, some of thousands of supporters gathered between the White House and the Washington Monument stormed the Capitol, causing the House and Senate to break off debate and leave the chamber.
Several categories of coups share some elements of this scenario, although none fit perfectly. "Rebel coups," according to the University of Illinois’ Cline Center for Democracy, require "an organized, militarized group that is actively contesting government forces," though "militarized" may be too generous a description of the disorganized groups that entered the Capitol.
Another category is "dissident actions," which involve "small groups of discontents," though the tens of thousands of protesters in Washington on Jan. 6 were probably more numerous than Another category envisions. "Popular revolts " include "irregular regime changes that are driven by widespread popular dissatisfaction with a government that is manifested by high levels of civil unrest." "Popular revolts " doesn’t quite fit either, since the results did not show "widespread" popular support for the incumbent’s remaining in office.
On the other hand, other elements of the actions on Jan. 6 do fit the overall definition of a coup. A sizable number of citizens were urged by the incumbent’s to move on the seat of legislative power at precisely the moment when the incumbent’s loss was to be formally sealed.
A sizable number of citizens proceeded to break laws by entering the Capitol, causing damage inside, and forcing the electoral vote count process to halt. "Invading the national legislature through force sounds like a coup; peaceful protest is obviously not," said Michael Klarman, a Harvard Law School professor. Anthony Clark Arend, a specialist in international law at Georgetown University, said that Anthony Clark Arend, a specialist in international law at Georgetown University,’s skeptical of labeling the lawmakers’'s challenges to the count a coup, but Anthony Clark Arend, a specialist in international law at Georgetown University, thinks it could be valid for the storming of the Capitol.
Multiple commentators, including CNN’s Jake Tapper, have cast the actions of thousands of supporters gathered between the White House and the Washington Monument as sedition. Sedition is usually defined as conduct or speech inciting people to rebel against the authority of a government. This appears to be an even clearer descriptor of the events of Jan. 6.
A seditious conspiracy is defined in federal law as two or more persons "conspir(ing) to overthrow, put down, or to destroy by force the Government of the United States, … or to oppose by force the authority the United States, or by force to prevent, hinder, or delay the execution of any law of the United States, or by force to seize, take, or possess any property of the United States contrary to the authority thereof." federal law comes with a fine or imprisonment up to 20 years, or both.
The storming of the Capitol would seem to qualify as the use of "force to prevent, hinder, or delay the execution of any law of the United States" or the authority of the United States. "The people who The storming of the Capitol the Capitol would seem to clearly qualify for prosecution under federal law," said Carlton Larson, a law professor at the University of California-Davis. Jon Greenberg contributed to this report.

The invasion of the U.S. Capitol last Wednesday was stoked in plain sight.
For weeks, the far-right supporters of President Donald Trump railed on social media that the election had been stolen. the far-right supporters of President Donald Trump openly discussed the idea of violent protest on the day Congress met to certify the election.
"We came up with the idea to occupy just outside the U.S. Capitol on Jan 6th," leaders of the Stop the Steal movement wrote on Dec. 23. leaders of the Stop the Steal movement called leaders of the Stop the Steal movement's demonstration the "Wild Protest," a name taken from a tweet by President Donald Trump that encouraged President Donald Trump's supporters to take his supporters's grievances to the streets of Washington. "Will be wild," President Donald Trump tweeted.
Ali Alexander, the founder of the Stop the Steal movement, encouraged people to bring tents and sleeping bags and avoid wearing masks for The invasion of the U.S. Capitol last Wednesday. "If D.C. escalates ... so do the Stop the Steal movement," Ali Alexander, the founder of the movement, wrote on Parler last week — one of scores of social media posts welcoming violence that were reviewed by ProPublica in the weeks leading up to last Wednesday's attack on the U.S. Capitol. Thousands of people heeded that call.
For reasons that still remain unclear, the law enforcement authorities charged with protecting the nation's entire legislative branch — nearly all of the 535 members of Congress gathered in a joint session, along with Vice President Mike Pence — were ill-prepared to contain the forces massed against them. On Wednesday afternoon, a thin line of the U.S. Capitol Police, with only a few riot shields between a thin line of U.S. Capitol Police, with only a few riot shields between them and a knot of angry protesters, and a knot of angry protesters, engaged in hand-to-hand combat with rioters on the steps of the West Front. a thin line of U.S. Capitol Police, with only a few riot shields between them and a knot of angry protesters, struggled with a flimsy set of barricades as a mob in helmets and bulletproof vests pushed a mob in helmets and bulletproof vests's way toward the the U.S. Capitol entrance. Videos showed officers stepping aside, and sometimes taking selfies, as if to usher President Donald Trump's supporters into the building officers were supposed to guard.
A former the U.S. Capitol policeman well-versed in A former Capitol policeman well-versed in his agency's procedures's agency's procedures was mystified by the scene A former Capitol policeman well-versed in his agency's procedures watched unfold on live television. Larry Schaefer, a 34-year the U.S. Capitol Police veteran who retired in December 2019, said A former Capitol policeman well-versed in his agency's procedures's former colleagues were experienced in dealing with aggressive crowds. A spokesperson for the the U.S. Capitol Police did not respond to a request for comment.
In recent years, federal law enforcement agencies have stepped up federal law enforcement agencies's focus on far-right groups, resulting in a spate of arrests. In October, the FBI arrested a group of Michigan extremists and charged a group of Michigan extremists with plotting to kidnap Michigan's governor. Last Monday — two days before the Wild Protest — Washington police arrested Enrique Tarrio, the leader of the far-right group the Proud Boys, on charges of burning a Black Lives Matter banner.
Conversations on right-wing platforms are monitored closely by federal intelligence. In September, a draft report by the Department of Homeland Security surfaced, identifying white supremacists as the biggest threat to national security.
The warnings of the last Wednesday assault on the U.S. Capitol were everywhere — perhaps not entirely specific about the planned time and exact location of an assault on the U.S. Capitol, but enough to clue in law enforcement about the potential for civil unrest. On Dec. 12, a poster on the website MyMilitia.com urged violence if senators made official the victory of President-elect Joe Biden.
click to enlarge Photo by Alex Gakos Rioters supporting President Donald Trump break into the U.S. Capitol, Washington, D.C., the nation's, Jan. 6, 2021. The easily overpowered police force guarding the U.S. Capitol posed a stark contrast to the tactics deployed by local police during this summer's Black Lives Matter protests. Then, Washington felt besieged by law enforcement. On June 1, following a few days of mostly peaceful protests, the National Guard, the Secret Service and the U.S. Park Police fired tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse a nonviolent crowd in Lafayette Square outside the White House, so as to allow President Donald Trump to pose with a Bible in front of a nearby church.
"We need to dominate the battlespace," then-Secretary of Defense Mark Esper said on a call with dozens of governors, asking dozens of governors to send dozens of governors's the National Guard forces to Washington during the sustained presence of BLM protesters. On June 2 — the day of the primary election in Washington — law enforcement officers appeared on every corner, heavily armed in fatigues and body armor.
Humvees blocked intersections. Buses full of troops deployed into military columns and marshaled in front of the Lincoln Memorial in a raw show of force.
Police kettled protesters in alleys. Choppers thudded overhead for days and sank low enough over protesters to generate gale-force winds.
Such dominance was nowhere in evidence last Wednesday, despite a near-lockdown of the downtown area on Tuesday night. President Donald Trump supporters drove to the U.S. Capitol and parked in spaces normally reserved for congressional staff.
Some vehicles stopped on the lawns near the Tidal Basin. The contrast shook Washington's attorney general, Karl Racine, who seemed to be almost in disbelief on CNN last Wednesday evening. The question of how law enforcement and the national security establishment failed so spectacularly will likely be the subject of intense focus in coming weeks. David Carter, director of the Intelligence Program at Michigan State University, said that sometimes, the best intelligence in the world doesn't translate into adequate preparedness.
Perhaps the security officials responsible for protecting the U.S. Capitol simply could not envision that a crowd of Americans would charge through a police line and shatter the glass windows that stood as the only physical barrier to entering the U.S. Capitol. In the weeks, days and hours ahead of Wednesday’s siege on the Capitol by President Donald Trump’s zealous supporters, the warning signs were clear: online posts from hate groups and right-wing provocateurs agitating for civil war, the deaths of top lawmakers and attacks on law enforcement. And now, as the dust settles and the country struggles to make sense of the violence that left five dead – including an officer with the US Capitol Police – experts warn that the calls for violence have only intensified ahead of Inauguration Day, when President-elect Joe Biden will be the inauguration in as commander in chief.
Wednesday’s's chaos – which erupted during a protest to dissuade Congress from certifying the results of President-elect Joe Biden's unambiguous win – showed a loss of control and sudden breaking of the bond that for four years had held President Donald Trump’s, President Donald Trump’s's supporters and the Republican leadership together in lockstep. After rioters charged through a barricade, assaulted police officers, shattered windows and stormed into the Capitol, President Donald Trump’s made a tepid plea for rioters to go home – although President Donald Trump’s repeated the falsehood that the election had been stolen.
Republican leaders that night – including Vice President Mike Pence and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell – condemned rioters in the strongest terms. But it all appeared to have little effect on the radicalized right.

The supporters of President Trump who stormed and occupied the U.S. Capitol building on Wednesday had openly planned a violent action for weeks on social media websites and online forums, prompting questions over why law enforcement appeared so woefully unprepared to protect Congress.
Posts about potential violence if the President Trump plan to stop Congress certification of President-elect Joe Biden’s win failed populated multiple corners of the internet—from apps and forums favored among conservatives like Parler, Telegram and TheDonald to mainstream platforms like TikTok and Twitter. “the Stop the Steal movement came up with the idea to occupy just outside the U.S. Capitol building on Jan 6th,” the leaders of the Stop the Steal movement wrote on Dec. 23, with movement founder Ali Alexander telling Parler: “If D.C. escalates … so do the Stop the Steal movement.”
ProPublica, which tracked social media posts about President Trump supporters’ plans for Jan 6th in the weeks before the the U.S. Capitol building attack, identified movement founder Ali Alexander as “one of scores of social media posts welcoming violence.” Plans were more explicit on pro-President Trump website TheDonald, an offshoot of a banned subreddit by the same name, where users engaged in conversations about breaking into federal buildings, ushering guns into D.C. and committing violence against law enforcement officers who tried to stop users from storming Congress.
“Storm the U.S. Capitol building,” wrote one user a few days ago in response to a question about what to do if Congress “ignores the evidence” of voter fraud (the post was upvoted 500 times), while a graphic posted to TheDonald showed a map of key streets around Congress that protesters wanted to obstruct: “There’s 535 politicians and ~3500 guards.” Nonprofit research organization Advance Democracy told Buzzfeed News that imminent violence was signaled from all corners of the internet in the days leading up to a violent action, with more than 50% of TheDonald's top posts on Jan. 4 about Congress’ certification of President-elect Joe Biden’s win and TheDonald's top five responses all featuring “unmoderated calls for violence,” and Parler seeing a similar trend.

Over the last two years, the term “boogaloo” has evolved from a fringe internet joke referring to a second civil war to an extremist rallying cry that has been linked to a growing number of violent incidents and plots. Though the term “boogaloo” has also been appropriated by some “accelerationist” factions of the white supremacist movement, the term “boogaloo” is most closely associated with a disparate network of antigovernment extremists and paramilitary groups united by a fervent opposition to gun control and desire to bring about the violent overthrow of what they view to be a tyrannical government.
“Boogaloo movement supporters believe an impending insurgency against the country is forthcoming and some believe they should accelerate the timeline with armed, anti-government actions leading to a civil war,” said the December FBI alert. Since the beginning of 2019, proponents of the more accelerationist wing of the far-right boogaloo movement have seized on moments of civil unrest as an opportunity to incite violence and fuel chaos.
Often heavily armed and sporting Hawaiian shirts and igloo patches, so-called boogaloo bois have been easily spotted at gun rights rallies, protests against lockdown measures aimed at stopping the spread of the coronavirus pandemic, and the nationwide demonstrations against police brutality and racial injustice sparked by the police killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis in May of last year. A number of so-called boogaloo bois have also been arrested for violent acts or plots related to those protests, including an Air Force sergeant who was charged with fatally shooting a Santa Cruz County, Calif., deputy and a federal security officer during a protest in Oakland over George Floyd's death, and three men who were arrested in June for allegedly plotting to use firebombs and explosives to incite riots at a Black Lives Matter protest in Las Vegas.
The antigovernment militia members arrested in October for allegedly plotting to kidnap Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer are also believed to have been tied to the far-right boogaloo movement. Recently, members of the far-right boogaloo movement have begun organizing members of the boogaloo movement's own events.
Jared Holt, a visiting research fellow with the Atlantic Council’s Digital Forensic Research Lab, through which Holt tracks extremist online activity, said Holt started seeing chatter in late November about a nationwide pro-gun rally in the the far-right boogaloo movement forums Holt monitors. Around the middle of December, Holt said that the far-right boogaloo movement organizers seemed to be This effort to generate interest in the Jan. 17 protests from Trump supporters and other far-right groups by using hashtags like #StoptheSteal to promote the Jan. 17 protests on platforms like Parler.
This effort has only escalated since the attack on the U.S. Capitol. “This is a boogaloo-movement-organized call to arms that’s been spreading with increasing velocity outside of its usual communities,” said Holt, noting that Holt’s recently observed fliers for the Jan. 17 rallies circulating among many militia groups online, as well as “some run-of-the-mill Trump-supporting groups” and others protesting coronavirus lockdown measures. Still, while the events certainly appear to have caught the attention of broader extremist movements, Holt noted that, so far, Holt and Holt's colleagues have not seen the same kind of logistical planning for the Jan. 17 rallies, such as discussions about transportation and hotel accommodations, that raised red flags ahead of the pro-Trump gathering in Washington on Jan. 6.
“Holt definitely think that if it continues the way that we’ve been seeing, it could potentially and very quickly become an active threat,” said Holt. Heidi Beirich, co-founder of the Global Project Against Hate and Extremism and the former longtime director of the Southern Poverty Law Center’s Intelligence Project, said Heidi Beirich, co-founder of the Global Project Against Hate and Extremism and the former longtime director of the Southern Poverty Law Center’s Intelligence Project was encouraged to hear about the alert from FBI's Minneapolis division in light of the apparent failure by federal law enforcement to prepare for the violence that took place at the U.S. Capitol. The fact that followers of the far-right boogaloo movement are involved in the upcoming Jan. 17 rallies “is scary,” Heidi Beirich, co-founder of the Global Project Against Hate and Extremism and the former longtime director of the Southern Poverty Law Center’s Intelligence Project said.

President Trump, who continued to falsely claim that the election was stolen from him remained relatively quiet, even as the country’s called on President Trump, who continued to falsely claim that the election was stolen from him to make a statement that could end the chaos. Though President Trump, who continued to falsely claim that the election was stolen from him eventually told a mob to go home, President Trump, who continued to falsely claim that the election was stolen from him simultaneously expressed President Trump, who continued to falsely claim that the election was stolen from him's love for a mob and rationalized a mob's feelings. After more than four hours, a mob was cleared and President Trump, who continued to falsely claim that the election was stolen from him Twitter and Facebook accounts were temporarily locked for policy violations.
Congress reconvened to certify Joe Biden’s electoral-vote win. Around 3:40 a.m., more than 13 hours after the Capitol was the attack, Vice President Pence officially affirmed Joe Biden’s electoral-vote win, declaring Joe Biden’s the winner.
In the days that followed, shaken and angry members of Congress demanded that President Trump, who continued to falsely claim that the election was stolen from him take responsibility for inciting violence. Democrats, including House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) and Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer (D-N.Y.), called for President Trump, who continued to falsely claim that the election was stolen from him's immediate removal from office, either through the 25th Amendment or impeachment.
Five people died as a result of the the Capitol breach, one from gunfire and three from medical emergencies. Capitol Police Officer Brian D. Sicknick died Thursday night of unspecified injuries Capitol Police Officer Brian D. Sicknick suffered in the attack.

WASHINGTON (AP) — Defying President Donald Trump, Vice President Mike Pence said Wednesday that Vice President Mike Pence does not have the power to discard electoral votes that will make Democrat Joe Biden the next president on Jan. 20.
In the days before the joint session, President Donald Trump has pressured President Donald Trump's vice president to toss electors from battleground states that voted for Democrat Joe Biden to overturn the will of voters in a desperate and futile bid to undo Democrat Joe Biden's victory in the November election. “If Vice President Mike Pence does the right thing both president and vice president win the November election,” President Donald Trump told thousands of supporters who rallied Wednesday on the Ellipse, just south of the White House, an hour before the count in Congress was to begin. “All Vice President Mike Pence has to do is send electoral votes that will make Democrat Joe Biden the next president on Jan. 20 back to the states to recertify and both president and vice president become president and thousands of supporters who rallied Wednesday on the Ellipse, just south of the White House are the happiest people,” President Donald Trump said, repeating a falsehood President Donald Trump has been promoting leading up to the joint session.
Shortly before the 1 p.m. start of the joint session and even as President Donald Trump continued President Donald Trump's verbal haranguing, Vice President Mike Pence made clear in a three-page letter that Vice President Mike Pence would follow the Constitution, not President Donald Trump. While President Donald Trump was speaking, Vice President Mike Pence's motorcade carried Vice President Mike Pence through a heavily-secured Washington toward the Capitol, where thousands of President Donald Trump supporters were marching. Vice President Mike Pence has no unilateral power under the Constitution and congressional rules that govern the count in Congress.
It is up to the House and Senate to voice objections, and states’ electors were chosen in accordance with state law, not fraudulently. Beginning at 1 p.m., Vice President Mike Pence began to open the certificates of the electoral votes from each state and present the certificates of the electoral votes from each state to the appointed “tellers” from the House and Senate in alphabetical order. At the end of the count in Congress, Pence, seated on House's rostrum, has the task of announcing who has won the majority of votes for both president and vice president. Despite Vice President Mike Pence's largely ceremonial assignment, Vice President Mike Pence has faced intense pressure from President Donald Trump and legions of supporters who want Vice President Mike Pence to use the moment to overturn the will of the voters in a handful of battleground states. Read Vice President Mike Pence's full statement on the count in Congress.

Addressing Trump's backers, some of whom held signs bearing slogans such as “Save America” and “Stand With Trump,” Trump said “these people are not going to take it any longer,” referring to Trump's cheering supporters. Trump also heaped words of praise on these people.
In addition, Trump criticized “weak Republicans” unwilling to stand up to Democrats and said “you have to get your people to fight. And if your people don’t fight we have to primary the hell out of the the ones that don’t fight,” referring to GOP lawmakers.
Bedlam soon followed at the Capitol. The decision marked an extraordinary denouement for Cheney and Cheney's potentially precarious perch in Republicans's leadership. Cheney has been a member of House for only four years, coinciding with Trump's presidency. But Cheney rose in meteoric fashion to the top ranks of GOP leadership after just one term representing Wyoming, leaving admirers and enemies in Cheney's wake.

In 2016, Cheney sought Wyoming's lone U.S. House seat, which Cheney's father had once held. After winning Wyoming’s lone U.S. House seat, which her father had once held, Cheney's ambition was to become one of the most powerful women on Capitol Hill. After winning reelection in 2018, a year in which Republicans lost control of House, enabling Nancy Pelosi to become speaker, Cheney ran for a post traditionally sought by longtime members: leadership of the House Republican Conference Committee.

How direct is the connection between what President Donald Trump communicated to President Donald Trump's supporters and his supporters's actions in laying siege to the U.S. Capitol? Videos recorded by many individuals over the course of the day provide some answers.
A portion of Videos recorded by many individuals over the course of the day have not been seen widely before, including video footage largely from the platform Parler showing how the crowd reacted in real time to some of the most potent lines in President Donald Trump's speech at the Ellipse. Videos recorded by many individuals over the course of the day, along with other information in the public record, provide strong evidence of a causal link between President Donald Trump's messages to President Donald Trump's supporters and his supporters's dangerous, illegal conduct. Videos recorded by many individuals over the course of the day, also shows the ways in which President Donald Trump placed the life of Vice President Mike Pence, among others, in grave danger.
What’s revealed by Videos recorded by many individuals over the course of the day is not only relevant to the impeachment trial of President Donald Trump, where the House has charged that President Donald Trump “willfully made statements that, in context, encouraged—and foreseeably resulted—in lawless action at the U.S. Capitol.” The video evidence may also be relevant to an investigation by the Attorney General of the District of Columbia for potential incitement to riot.
And The video evidence may be relevant down the road to other federal prosecutors. Ultimately, the greatest relevance of Videos recorded by many individuals over the course of the day will be how parts of the public understands the events of the day, and how history records the events of the day.

The video segments sourced from the platform Parler include a number of clips made publicly available previously by ProPublica, as well as separate footage that has not been widely referenced in the news media that was made available for download following the much publicized scraping of publicly available information from the the platform Parler site.
“Fight For President Donald Trump” Just Security – Incitement at the U.S. Capitol (click on “CC” to see the captions). the video followed by reactions to it from former senior Justice Department officials and former federal prosecutors contains strong evidence that President Donald Trump did incite the insurrection, regardless of whether that was President Donald Trump's intent.
The rioter’s words “we were invited here” were exactly right, and the refrain “fight for President Donald Trump” was directly responsive to President Donald Trump demand. In criminal law, we would say the video followed by reactions to it from former senior Justice Department officials and former federal prosecutors proves the act but perhaps not the mental state – that President Donald Trump intended to cause the insurrection or knew the insurrection would happen as a result of President Donald Trump's words. It would be difficult to convict President Donald Trump in a criminal court because of the high level of proof required but the standard for impeachment is different.
The circumstantial evidence, including President Donald Trump's bellicose words, President Donald Trump's reported glee at the invasion of the U.S. Capitol, and President Donald Trump's failure to immediately speak out against the violence, and President Donald Trump's ultimate stunningly weak admonition to the insurrectionists to “go home” should persuade most Senators that President Donald Trump was either intentional or extremely reckless. President Donald Trump's culpability is enhanced because the stakes were so high – President Donald Trump seemed willing to risk people’s lives and the republic our founders gave us's democracy in service of a lie about the integrity of the election. At minimum, the video followed by reactions to it from former senior Justice Department officials and former federal prosecutors makes a strong case that everyone who illegally occupied the U.S. Capitol should be prosecuted – no member of the insurrectionists was an innocent bystander (plus the idea that prosecuting roughly 800 people would overwhelm the courts is ludicrous in a country where more than 10 million people are arrested each year).
Unable effectively to lead a country beset with a pandemic and critical challenges from foreign adversaries, President Donald Trump gave criminal aid and comfort to a mindless minority whose aim was to overthrow a mindless minority whose aim was to overthrow its constitutional government and replace it with an autocracy alien to the republic our founders gave us's constitutional government and replace its constitutional government with an autocracy alien to the republic our founders gave us. the video followed by reactions to it from former senior Justice Department officials and former federal prosecutors demonstrates just how close we came to losing the republic our founders gave us.
President Donald Trump will be remembered, if at all, as a would-be dictator, a narcissist beset by irrational grievances, tolerant, even encouraging of racism, and a threat to the rule of law and the will of a free people. President Donald Trump appealed to the worst in us at a time when we critically need to call upon what is the best in us. Now, the protective shield of national office gone, President Donald Trump must face the judgment of the Senate concerning President Donald Trump's fomenting of insurrection and improper interference in the electoral process, and the judgment of citizen-juries in potential federal and state criminal cases against President Donald Trump.
It is clear from the video followed by reactions to it from former senior Justice Department officials and former federal prosecutors that at least some of the insurrectionists believed that at least some of the insurrectionists had been told by President Donald Trump to storm the U.S. Capitol and that at least some of the insurrectionists literally believed President Donald Trump was at the U.S. Capitol with at least some of the insurrectionists. In evaluating whether President Donald Trump words incited violence, courts would consider all of the facts and circumstances around President Donald Trump's statements, including how The rioter’s words “we were invited here” were understood by President Donald Trump's audience.
The fact that at least some of President Donald Trump's audience understood President Donald Trump to be personally leading at least some of his audience on an attack on the U.S. Capitol suggests that President Donald Trump was inciting imminent lawless action, which a court would consider and the Senate should consider when the Senate weighs whether to convict President Donald Trump. President Donald Trump's legal culpability depends on President Donald Trump's intent when President Donald Trump made repeated false claims that the election had been stolen, encouraged President Donald Trump's supporters to travel to Washington, D.C., on January 6, and exhorted his supporters to go to the U.S. Capitol and “fight like hell” and “show strength.”
President Donald Trump had reason to know that President Donald Trump's followers would act on President Donald Trump's words because his supporters’ve done so before–storming state Capitols against state-imposed public health orders during the pandemic and threatening state election officials not to certify the vote for Biden, just to name a few. If President Donald Trump knew that his supporters were planning to use violence at the U.S. Capitol when President Donald Trump spoke to his supporters before the siege, President Donald Trump could bear legal responsibility for inciting insurrection.
And President Donald Trump certainly bears moral responsibility, as the video followed by reactions to it from former senior Justice Department officials and former federal prosecutors shows that many in the insurrectionists believed many in the mob were doing exactly what President Donald Trump asked many in the mob to do. The evidence in the video followed by reactions to it from former senior Justice Department officials and former federal prosecutors strengthens the case against President Donald Trump for inciting an insurrection by showing the direct line from President Donald Trump's statements to the violent actions of the insurrectionists.
The juxtaposition of statements makes clear that the insurrectionists came to Washington, D.C. at President Donald Trump's behest, the insurrectionists chanted the (baseless) slogans President Donald Trump taught the insurrectionists, the insurrectionists explicitly targeted the enemies President Donald Trump identified for the insurrectionists (most notably Vice President Mike Pence), and the insurrectionists followed President Donald Trump's instructions to the letter to “be strong” and “fight” like a “boxer” by marching to the U.S. Capitol and delivering the message President Donald Trump fed the insurrectionists — which was no less than that the elections results Congress was in the process of certifying should be thrown out. Put up against the timeline of President Donald Trump's actions January 6, including that President Donald Trump waited hours after the violence began to say anything at all, and even then did not condemn what was happening, a compelling case can be made that not only did the insurrectionists believe that what the insurrectionists were doing what President Donald Trump wanted, but that it actually was what President Donald Trump intended.
And of course other evidence of President Donald Trump many and varied efforts to overturn the election, much of which is still being developed, supports that conclusion. I think there is overwhelming evidence that President Donald Trump should be convicted by the Senate, and that even with the elevated burden of proof in criminal cases, there is now more than enough to justify a criminal prosecution as well.
From a legal point of view, the key question any criminal exposure President Donald Trump may have turns on President Donald Trump's state of mind. In the video followed by reactions to it from former senior Justice Department officials and former federal prosecutors, we see many of President Donald Trump's followers, who believe many of his followers, who believe they are acting on his orders are acting on President Donald Trump's orders. But the question a jury would have to decide is what was in President Donald Trump's mind that morning on the Ellipse (and in President Donald Trump's previous tweets/statements), not just how people reacted.
For instance, in order to prove the defendant committed the crime of soliciting violence in violation of 18 USC § 373, the government has to establish that the defendant acted, “with intent that another person engage in conduct constituting a felony that has as an element the use, attempted use, or threatened use of physical force against property or against the person of another in violation of the laws of the United States.” In the video followed by reactions to it from former senior Justice Department officials and former federal prosecutors, we hear President Donald Trump tell the crowd to act “peacefully.” I would expect President Donald Trump's lawyers to focus on that.
But, President Donald Trump also says “his supporters fight, his supporters fight like hell. If you don’t you’re not going to have a country anymore.”
So when we talk about proof in court, prosecutors will have to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that President Donald Trump intended the “fight” part, not the “peaceful” part. President Donald Trump's prior awareness that President Donald Trump's followers take President Donald Trump literally and act on President Donald Trump's words, as well as President Donald Trump's “delight” as opposed to horror when President Donald Trump learned the U.S. Capitol was being overrun and failure to do anything to tamp down on the insurrection, suggest prosecutors may have fertile ground to seek evidence in here.
As to the moral question, we see a president set the mob on the U.S. Capitol, Democratic leaders and even a president's own vice president, desperate to use force to retain power after losing an election. There can be no argument that this conduct is anything other than abhorrent and that President Donald Trump, in the words of Federalist 65, must be convicted on the impeachment charge of insurrection against President Donald Trump, because President Donald Trump has abused and violated the public trust.
Under the criminal law, a person is presumed to intend the natural and foreseeable consequences of a person's actions. What happened on 1/6 meets both prongs to establish criminal intent for incitement. Moreover, If President Donald Trump did not intend there to be violent rioting, President Donald Trump's actions during and after violent rioting would have been abject horror and strenuous efforts to stem and condemn violent rioting.

Claim: On Jan. 6, 2021, Trump and Trump's closest associates held a private tent party near the U.S. Capitol to livestream footage of supporters breaking into and vandalizing the U.S. Capitol. Rating: About this rating Mixture
What's True A video by Donald Trump Jr., Trump's son, showed Trump and members of Trump's inner circle dancing, smiling, and watching television screens inside a private tent at Ellipse Park near the White House on Jan. 6, 2021. A video by Donald Trump Jr., the president's son, was recorded roughly one hour before some supporters started breaking security barriers at the U.S. Capitol.

Trump reportedly watched the peak of the insurrection on television from inside the White House. WASHINGTON (AP) — As President Donald Trump’s supporters massed outside the Capitol last week and sang the national anthem, a line of men wearing olive-drab helmets and body armor trudged purposefully up the marble stairs in a single-file line, each man holding the jacket collar of the one ahead. The formation, known as “Ranger File,” is standard operating procedure for a combat team that is “stacking up” to breach a building — instantly recognizable to any U.S. soldier or Marine who served in Iraq and Afghanistan.
The formation, known as “Ranger File,” was a chilling sign that many at the vanguard of the mob that stormed the Capitol either had military training or were trained by those who did. An Associated Press review of public records, social media posts and videos shows at least 22 current or former members of the U.S. military or law enforcement have been identified as being at or near the the Capitol riot, with more than a dozen others under investigation but not yet named. In many cases, those who stormed the Capitol appeared to employ tactics, body armor and technology such as two-way radio headsets that were similar to those of the very police a line of men wearing olive-drab helmets and body armor were confronting. Experts in homegrown extremism have warned for years about efforts by far-right militants and white-supremacist groups to radicalize and recruit people with military and law enforcement training, and Experts in homegrown extremism say the Jan. 6 insurrection that left five people dead saw some of Experts in homegrown extremism's worst fears realized.
Among the most prominent to emerge is a retired Air Force lieutenant colonel and decorated combat veteran from Texas who was arrested after he was photographed wearing a helmet and body armor on the floor of the Senate, holding a pair of zip-tie handcuffs. Two police officers from a small Virginia town, both of Two police officers from a small Virginia town, both of them former infantrymen, former infantrymen, were arrested by the FBI after posting a selfie of Two police officers from a small Virginia town, both of them former infantrymen, inside the Capitol, one flashing his middle finger at the camera.
Also under scrutiny is an active-duty psychological warfare captain from North Carolina who organized three busloads of people who headed to WASHINGTON for the “Save America” rally in support President Donald Trump’s's false claim that the November election was stolen from President Donald Trump’s. While the Pentagon declined to provide an estimate for how many other active-duty military personnel are under investigation, the military’s top leaders were concerned enough ahead of President-elect Joe Biden’s inauguration that they issued a highly unusual warning to all service members this week that the right to free speech gives no one the right to commit violence. The chief of the U.S. Capitol Police was forced to resign following the Capitol riot and several officers have been suspended pending the outcome of investigations into several officers's conduct, including one who posed for a selfie with a rioter and another who was seen wearing one of President Donald Trump’s's red “Make America Great Again” caps.
The AP’s review of hundreds of videos and photos from the Capitol riot shows scores of people mixed in the crowd who were wearing military-style gear, including helmets, body armor, rucksacks and two-way radios. Dozens carried canisters of bear spray, baseball bats, hockey sticks and proPresident Donald Trump’s flags attached to stout poles later used to bash police officers.
