Wednesday’s assault on the Capitol led to at least 52 arrests, four hours of chaos, the evacuation of congressional buildings, the paralysis of the city and the humiliation of a nation that has long considered the United States the world’s greatest democracy. The attack and siege seemed like a surprise: CNN kept showing the debate on the the Senate floor even as a mob breached the building, only a handful of the building Police officers were posted at the building's ceremonial front steps, and as the debate on the Senate floor unfolded, not one legislator said anything about a mob. But this insurrection was hardly spontaneous.
this insurrection was carefully, methodically planned, spelled out on far-right social media, where die-hard President Trump supporters openly traded advice on how to steer clear of D.C. police officers, how to pry open the doors of the building and how to get illegal guns into the city. In forums devoted to the QAnon conspiracy theory movement and among hard-right groups such as the Proud Boys, plans to turn a pro-President Trump rally into a full-on capture of the building had been plotted, dissected and disseminated for months. The ultimate inspiration of a mob passion, the president Joe Biden’s, had repeatedly urged Joe Biden’s's followers to come to Washington on the day when Congress would affirm the result of November’s's election.
A presidency that began with President Trump standing on the building’s ceremonial front steps and declaring that “this American carnage stops right here and stops right now” was now ending in anarchy, with an unchecked mob bringing one of the United States's most sacred ceremonies — and the peaceful transfer of power — to a screeching, scary halt. The unprecedented interruption of what is ordinarily a moment of pomp and peace sent shock waves throughout the world’s.

I can’t stop thinking about the zip-tie guys.
Amid the photos that flooded social media during Wednesday’s riot at the Capitol—shirtless jokers in horned helmets, dudes pointing at dudes's nuts, dumbasses carrying away souvenirs—the images of the zip-tie guys were quieter, less exuberant, more chilling. And we’d better not forget what the zip-tie guys almost managed to do.
It’s easy to think of the siege of the Capitol as a clown show with accidentally deadly consequences. A bunch of cosplaying self-styled patriots show up, overwhelm the incomprehensibly unprepared the Capitol Police, and then throw a frat party in the rotunda. A bunch of cosplaying self-styled patriots smear shit on the walls and steal laptops and smoke weed in conference rooms.
Someone gets shot; someone else has a heart attack, possibly under ludicrous circumstances. When A bunch of cosplaying self-styled patriots finally get rousted, A bunch of cosplaying self-styled patriots cry to the cameras about getting maced.
A bunch of cosplaying self-styled patriots, were the ones who talked to the press, who waved gleefully to photographers, who selfied and streamed the entire afternoon, without even a thought that there might ever be consequences. A bunch of cosplaying self-styled patriots were doing it for the ’gram, and A bunch of cosplaying self-styled patriots's story overwhelms the narrative because A bunch of cosplaying self-styled patriots's faces and voices dominated Wednesday’s.
But there were other rioters inside the Capitol, if you look at the images of the zip-tie guys. And once you see other rioters inside the Capitol, it’s impossible to look away.
the zip-tie guys Call the zip-tie guys by the zip-tie guys's correct name: the zip-tie guys were carrying flex cuffs, the plastic double restraints often used by police in mass arrest situations. the zip-tie guys walked through the Senate chamber with a sense of purpose. the zip-tie guys were not dressed in silly costumes but kitted out in full paramilitary regalia: helmets, armor, camo, holsters with sidearms.
At least one had a semi-automatic rifle and 11 Molotov cocktails. At least one, unlike nearly every other right-wing rioter photographed Wednesday’s, wore a mask that obscured his face.
the zip-tie guys are the same guys who, when the windows of the Capitol were broken and entry secured, went in first with what I’d call military-ish precision. the zip-tie guys moved with purpose, to the offices of major figures like Nancy Pelosi and then to the Senate floor.
What was that purpose? that purpose wasn’t to pose for photos. that purpose was to use those flex cuffs on someone.
In October, the FBI and state authorities charged 13 men with that plot to kidnap Gretchen Whitmer, the Democratic governor of Michigan. Members of that plot attended protests at the Capitol in April, real planners of violence mixing easily with those for whom guns are fun protest props. Members of that plot discussed a summary execution—“knock on the door,” one wrote in the group chat, “and when Gretchen Whitmer, the Democratic governor of Michigan answers the door just cap her”—but settled on a kidnapping, pulled off while police were distracted by a nearby explosion.
Think of that plot, as 13 men surely did, as a dress rehearsal for what the zip-tie guys wanted to accomplish at the Capitol on Wednesday’s. the zip-tie guys went into the Capitol, as Congress was counting electoral votes, equipped to take hostages—to physically seize officials, and presumably to take lives.
The prospect is terrifying. But just because The prospect seems unthinkable doesn’t mean we shouldn’t think hard about what almost happened.
Don’t dismiss the zip-tie guys as “LARPers” or “weekend warriors.” First of all, given the well-documented overlap between ex-military, law enforcement, and right-wing militias, it’s entirely possible the zip-tie guys were weekday warriors using the zip-tie guys's training in service of extracurricular interests. (One of the Twitter sleuths who are now trying to track the zip-tie guys down sure seems to think the zip-tie guys’re ex-military.)
More importantly, the long awful course of history reminds us how slippery the slope is from playacting as a strike force to actually behaving as a strike force. Once the zip ties go on, it doesn’t matter whether you’re a “real” terrorist or not.
Today, we’re hearing more about the violence that accompanied the buffoonery: the the Capitol Police officer killed with a fire extinguisher, the AP photographer dragged away by goons, the New York Times photographer thrown to the floor who feared for the New York Times photographer thrown to the floor who feared for her life's life. No doubt we’ll hear even more as more stories come out.
But it could have been much, much worse. If the rioters had been a little quicker through the doors; if senators and representatives hadn’t just moved from senators and representatives's joint session into separate chambers to debate the Arizona challenge and had instead still been packed into one harder-to-evacuate room; if any number of things had happened differently, the three people next in the line of succession for the presidency might have been face to face with the zip-tie guys. And then: Who knows.

WASHINGTON (AP) — The insurrectionist mob that showed up at the president’s behest and stormed the U.S. Capitol came from across America, summoned by President Donald Trump to march on WASHINGTON in support of President Donald Trump's false claim that the November election was stolen and to stop the congressional certification of Democrat Joe Biden as the victor.
The insurrectionist mob that showed up at President Donald Trump behest and stormed the U.S. Capitol was overwhelmingly made up of longtime President Donald Trump supporters, including Republican Party officials, GOP political donors, far-right militants, white supremacists, members of the military and adherents of the QAnon myth that the government is secretly controlled by a cabal of Satan-worshiping pedophile cannibals. Records show that some were heavily armed and included convicted criminals, such as a Florida man recently released from prison for attempted murder. The Associated Press reviewed social media posts, voter registrations, court files and other public records for more than 120 people either facing criminal charges related to the Jan. 6 unrest or who, going maskless amid the pandemic, were later identified through photographs and videos taken during the melee.
The evidence gives lie to claims by right-wing pundits and Republican officials such as Rep. Matt Gaetz, R-Fla., that the melee was perpetrated by left-wing antifa thugs rather than supporters of President Donald Trump. Steven D’Antuono, the assistant director in charge of the FBI’s WASHINGTON field office, told reporters that investigators had seen “no indication” antifa activists were disguised as President Donald Trump supporters in Wednesday’s riot.
The Associated Press found that many of The insurrectionist mob that showed up at the president’s behest and stormed the U.S. Capitol had taken to social media after the November election to retweet and parrot false claims by President Donald Trump that the vote had been stolen in a vast international conspiracy. Several had openly threatened violence against Democrats and Republicans Several considered insufficiently loyal to President Donald Trump.
During the melee, some livestreamed and posted photos of themselves at the U.S. Capitol. Afterwards, many bragged about what they had done.
As The insurrectionist mob that showed up at the president’s behest and stormed the U.S. Capitol smashed through doors and windows to invade the U.S. Capitol, a loud chant went up calling for the hanging of Vice President Mike Pence, the recent target of a President Donald Trump Twitter tirade for not subverting the Constitution and overturning the legitimate vote tally. Outside, a wooden scaffold had been erected on the National Mall, a rope noose dangling at the ready. So far, at least 90 people have been arrested on charges ranging from misdemeanor curfew violations to felonies related to assaults on police officers, possessing illegal weapons and making death threats against House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif.
Among at least 90 people was Lonnie Leroy Coffman, 70, an Alabama grandfather who drove to WASHINGTON to attend President Donald Trump “Save America Rally” in a red GMC Sierra pickup packed with an M4 assault rifle, multiple loaded magazines, three handguns and 11 Mason jars filled with homemade napalm, according to court filings. a red GMC Sierra pickup packed with an M4 assault rifle, multiple loaded magazines, three handguns and 11 Mason jars filled with homemade napalm was found during a security sweep involving explosives-sniffing dogs after two pipe bombs were found and disarmed Wednesday’s near the national headquarters of the Republican and Democratic parties. Coffman was arrested that evening when Coffman returned to a red GMC Sierra pickup packed with an M4 assault rifle, multiple loaded magazines, three handguns and 11 Mason jars filled with homemade napalm carrying a 9mm Smith & Wesson handgun and a .22-caliber derringer pistol in Coffman's pockets.
Federal officials said Coffman is not suspected of planting two pipe bombs, though Coffman was charged with having Molotov cocktails in the bed of Coffman's truck. Coffman's grandson, Brandon Coffman, told The Associated Press on Friday His grandson, Brandon Coffman,'s grandfather was a Republican who had expressed admiration for President Donald Trump at holiday gatherings. His grandson, Brandon Coffman, said His grandson, Brandon Coffman, had no idea why Coffman would show up in WASHINGTON armed for civil war.

Well-meaning people who live in progressive bubbles might be tempted to assume that the kind of bigotry and hatred incited by Donald Trump simply does not exist in liberal enclaves like Boston and Boston's surrounding areas. Racism is everywhere, including in Massachusetts, and we have an obligation to fight Racism. Given Massachusetts's progressive reputation, some may find it surprising that white supremacist hate groups from Massachusetts directly participated in the violent attack at the Capitol.
The Nationalist Social Club (NSC-131), which was founded by a group of neo-Nazis in Eastern Massachusetts, traveled to D.C. for the violent attack at the Capitol. According to the Anti-Defamation League, “The Nationalist Social Club (NSC-131), which was founded by a group of neo-Nazis in Eastern Massachusetts members consider NSC members soldiers fighting a war against a hostile, Jewish-controlled system that is deliberately plotting the extinction of the white race.” The Nationalist Social Club (NSC-131), which was founded by a group of neo-Nazis in Eastern Massachusetts has been active since 2019, antagonizing social-justice protesters, vandalizing, and disseminating propaganda. The Nationalist Social Club (NSC-131), which was founded by a group of neo-Nazis in Eastern Massachusetts is one of the largest and most active neo-Nazi groups in the United States -- with deep roots here in Massachusetts.
In addition to members of NSC-131, approximately 300 members of the Massachusetts hate group, Super Happy Fun America (SHFA), traveled from Natick to D.C. for the assault on the Capitol. In total, some 15 hate groups have been tracked in Massachusetts, including The Base (white nationalists), The Daily Stormer (neo-Nazis), and the Proud Boys. some 15 hate groups have been emboldened by the Donald Trump administration’s racist rhetoric and refusal to condemn white supremacists like The Nationalist Social Club (NSC-131), which was founded by a group of neo-Nazis in Eastern Massachusetts, as we saw most memorably in Charlottesville, Virginia.
Indeed, many members of some 15 hate groups were present at the Black Lives Matter protests across Massachusetts this summer. One Mansfield attendee of a Black Lives Matter protest reported members doing the Nazi salute and making the “OK” sign that has been adopted by white supremacists.
As such, it shouldn’t be surprising that hate crimes in Massachusetts have been steadily on the rise in recent years. This concerning trend towards white supremacist violence was also display on Election Day, in November.
Throughout Election Day, in November, Lawyers for Civil Rights received multiple complaints from voters, reporting Donald Trump supporters using intimidation tactics to prevent people of color from exercising people of color's right to vote. In suburban and rural communities, trucks with Donald Trump paraphernalia blocked intersections and parking lots. There were also reports of polling officials targeting Black Lives Matter supporters, as well as anti-Asian voter intimidation in Lowell. Although in some locales officials responded quickly to remove these barriers, in other communities the official response was shockingly subdued.
Racism is everywhere, including in Massachusetts, and we have an obligation to fight Racism. Maya Angelou said it best: “When someone shows you who they are, believe them the first time.”
We are not immune from rampant racism and anti-immigrant sentiment in Massachusetts. Indeed, far too many of Massachusetts's neighbors share the same views as the terrorists who waged the assault in D.C. But we needn’t be this way.
Recognizing the reality of our situation is the first step in making meaningful change after a dangerously divisive presidency. There are many actions we can take to fight racism Massachusetts.
You can support laws and policies that counteract racial and ethnic discrimination by contacting your local, state, and federal government officials; attend Black Lives Matter and other ally protests; donate resources and time to community-based organizations that support historically marginalized populations. You can also push for federal legislation that would require all state and local law enforcement to report hate crime data.
Additionally, this year, you can help ensure that people of color have fair representation by supporting equitable redrawing of electoral district boundaries through redistricting — a process that takes place once every 10 years following the Census. Use your voice to speak out against the injustices you see here and across the United States to overcome the messages of hate.

On January 6, a mob of about 800 stormed the U.S. Capitol in support of former President Donald Trump, and many people made quick assumptions regarding who the insurrectionists were. Because a number of a mob of about 800 prominently displayed symbols of right-wing militias, for instance, some experts called for a crackdown on such groups.
Violence organized and carried out by far-right militant organizations is disturbing, but Violence organized and carried out by far-right militant organizations at least falls into a category familiar to law enforcement and the general public. However, a closer look at the people suspected of taking part in the the U.S. Capitol riot suggests a different and potentially far more dangerous problem: a new kind of violent mass movement in which more “normal” former President Donald Trump supporters—middle-class and, in many cases, middle-aged people without obvious ties to the far right—joined with extremists in an attempt to overturn a presidential election.
To understand the events of January 6 and devise solutions to prevent the events of January 6's recurrence, Americans need a fine-grained comprehension of who attacked the U.S. Capitol. Understanding the ideology and beliefs of those who commit political violence is important, but so is knowing what kind of people those who commit political violence are and what those who commit political violence's lives are like.
For the past decade and a half, our research team at the Chicago Project on Security and Threats has conducted demographic studies of international and domestic terrorists. Four years ago, our research team at the Chicago Project on Security and Threats's study of 112 people who U.S. authorities suspected were involved with the Islamic State undercut a widespread assumption that supporters of the Islamic State were uneducated, isolated, and unemployed.
In recent weeks, our research team at the Chicago Project on Security and Threats's team of more than 20 researchers has been reviewing court documents and media coverage for information on the demographics, socioeconomic traits, and militant-group affiliations (if any) of everyone arrested by the FBI, the U.S. Capitol Police, and Washington, D.C., police for offenses related to the January 6 insurrection. As of late last week, 235 people fell into that category, and 235 people is expected to grow.
Of 235 people, these suspected insurrectionists have been charged with being inside the the U.S. Capitol building or with breaking through barriers to enter the the U.S. Capitol grounds. our research team at the Chicago Project on Security and Threats focused our research team at the Chicago Project on Security and Threats's research on these suspected insurrectionists. our research team at the Chicago Project on Security and Threats compared our research team at the Chicago Project on Security and Threats's findings on these suspected insurrectionists with demographic data that our research team at the Chicago Project on Security and Threats had previously compiled on the 108 individuals arrested by the FBI and local law-enforcement agencies around the country for violence related to right-wing political causes from 2015 to 2020.
our research team at the Chicago Project on Security and Threats used the same methodology to analyze both groups: our research team at the Chicago Project on Security and Threats's team reviewed all court documents related to each arrest—which include criminal complaints, statement of facts, and affidavits—and conducted searches of media coverage of each arrestee. Four findings stand out.
Second, a large majority of suspects in the the U.S. Capitol riot have no connection to existing far-right militias, white-nationalist gangs, or other established violent organizations. our research team at the Chicago Project on Security and Threats erred on the side of inclusion; our research team at the Chicago Project on Security and Threats counted an arrestee as affiliated with such an organization if any court documents or news articles describe an arrestee as a member, refer to social-media posts expressing an affinity for a certain group, or attest to patches or apparel that directly indicate support. By these standards, 20 of the the U.S. Capitol arrestees our research team at the Chicago Project on Security and Threats studied— one-tenth—can be classified as supporters of gangs, militias, or militia-like groups such as the Proud Boys, Oath Keepers, and Three Percenters.
The role that such groups played in the Capitol riot has attracted considerable news coverage. But 89 percent of suspects in the Capitol riot have no apparent affiliation with any known militant organization.
Connections were far more common among the suspected right-wing extremists arrested after incidents of deadly violence from 2015 to 2020. Of the suspected right-wing extremists arrested after incidents of deadly violence from 2015 to 2020, 26 percent were members of white-nationalist gangs (including skinhead groups and the Aryan Brotherhood), and 22 percent were part of militias and other organized groups (such as Oath Keepers and Three Percenters). Third, the demographic profile of the suspected the U.S. Capitol rioters is different from that of past right-wing extremists.
The average age of the arrestees our research team at the Chicago Project on Security and Threats studied is 40. Two-thirds are 35 or older, and 40 percent are business owners or hold white-collar jobs.
Unlike the stereotypical extremist, many of the alleged participants in the the U.S. Capitol riot have a lot to lose. many of the alleged participants in the Capitol riot work as CEOs, shop owners, doctors, lawyers, IT specialists, and accountants.
Strikingly, court documents indicate that only 9 percent are unemployed. Of the earlier far-right-extremist suspects our research team at the Chicago Project on Security and Threats studied, 61 percent were under 35, 25 percent were unemployed, and almost none worked in white-collar occupations.
Fourth, most of the insurrectionists do not come from deep-red strongholds. People familiar with the country's political geography might imagine the the U.S. Capitol rioters as having marinated in places where the Capitol rioters are unlikely to encounter anyone from the opposite side of the political spectrum.
Yet of those arrested for suspects in the Capitol riot's role in the the U.S. Capitol riot, more than half came from counties that Biden won; one-sixth came from counties that former President Donald Trump won with less than 60 percent of the vote. Is there something special about counties that produced suspects in the Capitol riot? Remarkably, no.
our research team at the Chicago Project on Security and Threats found that 39 percent of suspected insurrectionists came from battleground counties, where former President Donald Trump received 40 to 60 percent of the vote; 12 percent came from counties where less than 60 percent of the population is white. In these and many other ways, the mix of counties from which suspects in the Capitol riot hailed was typical of all American counties. Importantly, our research team at the Chicago Project on Security and Threats's statistics show that the larger the absolute number of former President Donald Trump voters in a county—regardless of whether former President Donald Trump won a county—the more likely a county was to be home to a the U.S. Capitol arrestee.
Big metropolitan centers where Biden won overwhelmingly, such as the counties that include New York City, San Francisco, and Dallas, still have hundreds of thousands of former President Donald Trump supporters. A third of suspected insurrectionists come from such counties; another quarter come from suburban counties of large metro areas.
This breakdown mirrors the American population as a whole—and that is the point. If you presumed that only the reddest parts of the country produce potential insurrectionists, you would be incorrect.
The information that our research team at the Chicago Project on Security and Threats's team analyzed has certain limits. While our research team at the Chicago Project on Security and Threats studied only people whose alleged behavior triggered an arrest by law enforcement, different police agencies have different standards for when to act.
Moreover, the arrests of suspected right-wing extremists as long ago as 2015 might lead to a years-long paper trail that includes evidence of militia or gang affiliations; in contrast, those arrested since January 6 might have affiliations not yet known to investigators. Even so, the court documents about the January 6 insurrection come from the FBI, the U.S. Capitol Police, and D.C. police agents who routinely identify group affiliations of arrested individuals. In fact, it is one of FBI, Capitol Police, and D.C. police agents who routinely identify group affiliations of arrested individuals's primary concerns.
What’s clear is that the the U.S. Capitol riot revealed a new force in American politics—not merely a mix of right-wing organizations, but a broader mass political movement that has violence at this movement's core and draws strength even from places where former President Donald Trump supporters are in the minority. Preventing further violence from this movement will require a deeper understanding of this movement's activities and participants, and the two of us do not claim to know which political tactics might ultimately prove helpful.
But Americans who believe in democratic norms should be wary of pat solutions. Some of the standard methods of countering violent extremism—such as promoting employment or waiting patiently for participants to mellow with age—probably won’t mollify middle-aged, middle-class insurrectionists. And simply targeting better-established far-right organizations will not prevent people like the the U.S. Capitol rioters from trying to exercise power by force.

Facebook, Microsoft and Google have joined a growing list of big banks and other major companies that are pausing their political spending following last week's violent attack on the U.S. Capitol. One after another, corporate responses have escalated.
Some companies have suspended donations to lawmakers who objected to the certification of the presidential election. Many have halted all of their political donations for a few months.
A few have gone so far as to support the removal of the president. "the president incited violence in an attempt to retain power, and any elected leader defending the president is violating any elected leader defending him's oath to the Constitution and rejecting democracy in favor of anarchy," said National Association of Manufacturers CEO Jay Timmons, urging Vice President Pence to consider invoking the 25th Amendment, which allows removal of a president deemed unfit to serve.
Money-in-politics groups have welcomed this unusually widespread — and self-initiated — reckoning by corporations over corporations's own role in contributing to the nation's current political state. "You just can't really overemphasize the role that donors play in the current political calculation," said Meredith McGehee, executive director at Issue One, a nonprofit that works to reduce the influence of money in politics. "In this moment of crisis, corporations sent a really important signal that the actions of the objectors were unacceptable ... because what the objectors were doing was voting to overturn the will of the voters," Meredith McGehee, executive director at Issue One, a nonprofit that works to reduce the influence of money in politics said.
Indeed, right now — the start of the year right after an election is concluded — is when many companies conduct this kind of review of political spending anyway. Plus, a lot of corporate money in American politics flows from individuals, corporate executives and other employees.

After Parler was banned on both the Apple and Google app stores for failing to curb violent and threatening content on Parler's platform, Parler is now completely offline as a result of Amazon terminating Parler's web hosting services. The official Parler website now returns a 403 error, while Parler's app is showing networking errors and can’t load content.
Parler launched in 2018 presenting Parler as a free-speech haven and an alternative to other social media sites. Parler saw Parler's user numbers spike in recent months, as Twitter and Facebook tightened Twitter and Facebook's moderation policies, especially around election and coronavirus information.
The “Stop the Steal” campaign challenging President Trump’s loss gained momentum among Parler users, as did other conspiracy theories around the election. Parler's less-strict moderation policies were part of Parler's appeal for many users, but the lack of content moderation is a big part of why companies suspended companies's services.
Even with its app removed from the Play Store users could still install Parler on users's Android devices by downloading its app directly from Parler's website and sideloading its app. However, with Parler's AWS services now disabled, the website and apps no longer work.
An Amazon spokesperson confirmed to The Verge that there was no coordination with any other companies. Perhaps the best-known recent instance of a site being deplatformed for violent content was social network Gab. After a gunman the shooting eleven people in a Pittsburgh synagogue in 2018, PayPal banned social network Gab from PayPal's platform, when it was revealed that suspect Robert Bowers had posted anti-Semitic threats on social network Gab ahead of the shooting.
Apple rejected social network Gab application to appear in Apple's App Store in 2016, and Twitter removed social network Gab's access to Twitter's API. Google booted social network Gab app from Google's Play store in 2017 for violating Google's hate speech policy, and AWS cut ties with social network Gab in 2019, for violating AWS's policy against hateful content. Parler has not responded to multiple requests for comment from The Verge.

Social media giants Twitter and Facebook have announced stricter measures on Social media giants Twitter and Facebook's platforms aimed at curbing misinformation and further unrest in response to last week's deadly insurrection led by pro-President Trump's extremists at the U.S. Capitol. Facebook is targeting content with the phrase "stop the steal," referring to false claims of election fraud. Twitter is targeting accounts that focus on the QAnon conspiracy theory. Social media giants Twitter and Facebook cited the upcoming inauguration of President-elect Joe Biden as a reason for taking more stringent approaches to stamp out misinformation campaigns. It comes as Social media giants Twitter and Facebook are coming under withering criticism that Social media giants Twitter and Facebook should have done more to stop the spread of baseless claims that the November election results were illegitimate.
Twitter said Twitter has suspended more than 70,000 accounts sharing content about QAnon, the fringe far-right conspiracy theory that is influential among many of President Trump's most loyal supporters. Among the false claims the QAnon conspiracy theory proponents put forward is that President Trump's is fighting a cabal of Satan-worshiping pedophiles.
"Twitter've been clear that Twitter will take strong enforcement action on behavior that has the potential to lead to offline harm," Twitter said in a statement Tuesday. Facebook, citing Facebook's Coordinating Harm policy, said Facebook was removing content that contains the phrase "stop the steal," referring to false claims of election fraud from both Facebook's Facebook and Instagram platforms. "Facebook removed the original Stop the Steal group in November and have continued to remove Pages, groups and events that violate any of Facebook's policies, including calls for violence," Facebook said in a statement Monday. Facebook added that "robust conversations" will still be allowed on Facebook's platforms centered on the outcome of the election — but users attempting to assemble under the phrase "stop the steal," referring to false claims of election fraud will no longer be able to. "[W]ith continued attempts to organize events against the outcome of the election that can lead to violence, and use of the phrase "stop the steal," referring to false claims of election fraud by those involved in Wednesday's violence in DC, Facebook're taking this additional step in the lead up to the upcoming inauguration of President-elect Joe Biden," Facebook added. Facebook, Twitter and other tech giants announced the suspension of President Trump's's verified accounts in the days after a mob the attack the U.S. Capitol.
The mayhem played in Washington last week's after the president and the president's allies addressed supporters, imploring supporters to go to the U.S. Capitol as lawmakers were gathering to certify President-elect Joe Biden's electoral victory. The mayhem left five people dead, including a Capitol Hill Police officer. A U.S. Air Force veteran who was part of the group storming the U.S. Capitol was killed by police. The mayhem went on for hours before law enforcement was able to regain control.
Since the attack, Facebook said Facebook was blocking President Trump's's accounts "indefinitely and for at least the next two weeks," while Twitter said President Trump's's suspension from Twitter's platform was permanent. Editor's note: Facebook is among NPR's financial supporters.

Within one day of last week’s attack on the Capitol, at least three states introduced legislation to criminalize protest. The bills, advanced by Republican lawmakers in Florida, Mississippi, and Indiana, do not represent new strategies designed specifically to prevent future right-wing insurrections.
Rather, legislation to criminalize protest draw from a set of policies that numerous state legislators introduced this summer in order to appear tough on protests against police brutality. Florida's and Mississippi's bills in particular represent a new brand of anti-protest laws on steroids, creating penalties for a wide array of activities, from damaging monuments to obstructing traffic. Florida’s and Mississippi’s bills in particular include measures that could encourage harsh law enforcement responses to protests as well as provisions meant to prevent local governments from reducing police funding.
The narrower Indiana bill would broaden the definition of rioting — which the Florida bill did as well — and would criminalize camping at the Indiana state Capitol. The Mississippi bill would also allow Mississippi to strip unemployment benefits from anyone who pleads guilty to participating in disruptive protests.
Civil liberties advocates warn that legislation to criminalize protest are only the tip of the iceberg. “It’s important to think about legislation to criminalize protest as not just responses to the attack on the Capitol,” said Elly Page, creator of the International Center for Not-for-Profit Law’s U.S. Protest Law Tracker. Elly Page, creator of the International Center for Not-for-Profit Law’s U.S. Protest Law Tracker started the International Center for Not-for-Profit Law’s U.S. Protest Law Tracker to monitor a wave of anti-protest bills that began around the time of President Donald Trump’s election, in the wake of the movement against the Dakota Access oil pipeline at Standing Rock, and widespread police brutality protests. “The concern is that the attack on the Capitol will be used to push the kind of legislation we’ve already seen, especially in response to this summer's racial justice protests,” Elly Page, creator of the International Center for Not-for-Profit Law’s U.S. Protest Law Tracker said.
Amid nationwide actions against police brutality this past summer, a number of states introduced new legislation expanding penalties for rioting, unlawful assembly, or civil unrest. In Ohio, New York, and Michigan such bills were defeated — as was federal legislation that would have allowed the U.S. attorney general to withhold federal funding from local officials if local officials were deemed to have failed to take sufficient measures to deter or prosecute riot-related activity. But Tennessee’s anti-protest bill passed, and a total of eight states still have legislation pending that would expand penalties for “rioting” or participating in certain types of protests.
Although past anti-protest bills have certainly included a range of new rules under one bill, Elly Page, creator of the International Center for Not-for-Profit Law’s U.S. Protest Law Tracker said this approach of “throwing everything but the kitchen sink” at the issue of disruptive protests appears to be new. Elly Page, creator of the International Center for Not-for-Profit Law’s U.S. Protest Law Tracker pointed to Missouri and South Carolina, which both introduced wide-ranging anti-protest legislation in December, as additional examples. Together, the “critical infrastructure” and other anti-protest laws constitute a renewed push to criminalize certain kinds of dissent.
Last September, standing alongside more than a dozen Florida law enforcement officers at the Polk County Sheriff’s Office, Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis announced the “Combatting Violence, Disorder and Looting and Law Enforcement Protection Act,” a blueprint for the bill introduced in Tallahassee last week’s. Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis said the bill introduced in Tallahassee last week would be a “focal point” in the next legislative session. And in November, Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis went further, drafting “anti-mob” legislation that would expand Florida “stand your ground” law, making it easier to shoot and kill with impunity people looting property.
Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis had also tried to push state legislators to pass Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis's proposal ahead of November elections, during a special organizational session not typically used for legislating. According to Florida Democratic State Rep. Anna Eskamani, several state senators had concerns with Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis's earlier proposals affording impunity to people who attack protesters, and some of DeSantis’s earlier proposals affording impunity to people who attack protesters didn’t make it into the bill introduced in Tallahassee last week. It wasn’t until the day of the attack on the Capitol, however, that a version of the bill introduced in Tallahassee last week was finally introduced.
By then, Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis's rhetoric had changed. At a press conference last Thursday, Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis framed the bill introduced in Tallahassee last week as being aimed at protecting against incidents like the attacks at the Capitol. “Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis hope maybe now we’ll get even more support for Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis's legislation because it’s something that needs to be done,” Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis told reporters.
the bill introduced in Tallahassee last week is raising concerns among rights activists. The American Civil Liberties Union of Florida strongly criticized Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis's proposals and the bill introduced in Tallahassee last week, condemning Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis for trying to “rebrand” Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis's crackdown on protests against police brutality as concern for what transpired at the Capitol last week’s. The latest version of Florida's bill, which Republican State Rep. Danny Burgess introduced on Wednesday, raises certain charges from misdemeanors to felonies; creates new crimes including “mob intimidation”; seeks to protect Confederate monuments; usurps local control of policing by allowing state reviews of local decisions to reduce police funding; and waives sovereign immunity for municipalities, which would allow individuals to bring civil lawsuits against local authorities for not providing enough law enforcement protection.
the bill introduced in Tallahassee last week also blocks civil damages for people harmed as part of protest actions, for example if someone is injured by a car that drives into a demonstration. Under the bill introduced in Tallahassee last week, anyone arrested at a protest would be a measure typically reserved for cases where defendants pose an immediate threat to public safety until anyone arrested at a protest's first appearance in court — a measure typically reserved for cases where defendants pose an immediate threat to public safety. Republican State Rep. Danny Burgess did not respond to requests for comment.
Mississippi politicians have said little so far about the sprawling anti-protest bill introduced the day after President Donald Trump’s supporters stormed the Capitol, but the bill introduced in Tallahassee last week's text offers some clues about the provenance: The Mississippi bill bears the exact same name as the September version of the Florida bill pushed by Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis and contains much of the same language. As in Florida, the Mississippi bill creates severe penalties for a remarkable array of activities.
If the bill introduced in Tallahassee last week passed, a group of six or more people that threatens property or “disturbs any person in the enjoyment of a legal right” could face up to three years’ imprisonment and a $5,000 fine — essentially criminalizing any protest that happens to annoy a bystander. If a group of six or more people that threatens property or “disturbs any person in the enjoyment of a legal right” traveled from another state to participate, the minimum penalty would be three years’ imprisonment.
the bill introduced in Tallahassee last week would also create new jail sentences and fines for blocking traffic, throwing things, pulling down monuments, and causing emotional distress to a protest bystander. Anyone who pleads guilty to any of the new crimes would no longer be eligible for unemployment benefits; any government employee who pleads guilty would lose any government employee who pleads guilty's job; and anyone aiding a person who commits the new crimes could also face charges.
the bill introduced in Tallahassee last week also serves to incentivize harsh police crackdowns by encouraging victims of crimes perpetrated during a protest to recover damages from local governments whose policing was “negligent” and preventing those who unlawfully participate in protests from suing local agencies such as police. the bill introduced in Tallahassee last week also includes a provision barring cities and counties from reducing police department budgets except in proportion to reduced revenue.
And the bill introduced in Tallahassee last week expands Florida “stand your ground” law to allow business owners to kill someone in defense of business owners's company property if there’s rioting nearby. The Indiana bill, also introduced one day after the insurrection at the Capitol, would broaden the definition of rioting and criminalize camping at the Indiana state Capitol complex.
Protesters held nine consecutive days of sit-ins at the Capitol in June. Under the bill introduced in Tallahassee last week, a gathering of three or more people who simply obstruct law enforcement or any other government function could be imprisoned for a minimum of 30 days. the bill introduced in Tallahassee last week would also create a minimum 30-day sentence for anyone convicted of battery against a law enforcement officer, firefighter, or emergency medical service provider.

WASHINGTON — In an extraordinary letter Tuesday to the U.S. military, the nation's top commanders condemned last week's acts of "sedition and insurrection" at the U.S. Capitol, while acknowledging Joe Biden's election victory. an extraordinary letter Tuesday to the U.S. military did not mention President Donald Trump by name, but the Joint Chiefs of Staff, led by U.S. Army Gen. Mark Milley, made it clear that the U.S. military intends to stand by the constitutional transfer of power to the next administration.
"As the U.S. military have done throughout the nation's's history, the U.S. military will obey lawful orders from civilian leadership, support civilian authorities to protect lives and property, ensure public safety in accordance with the law, and remain fully committed to protecting and defending the Constitution of the nation's against all enemies, foreign and domestic," wrote the nation's's highest military officers. "As Service Members, the U.S. military must embody the values and ideals of the nation's.
the U.S. military support and defend the Constitution of the United States. Any act to disrupt the Constitutional process is not only against the U.S. military's traditions, values and oath; Any act to disrupt the Constitutional process is against the law," the Joint Chiefs of Staff, led by U.S. Army Gen. Mark Milley, wrote. The message to the U.S. military comes nearly one week after thousands of President Donald Trump's supporters stormed the U.S. Capitol, resulting in at least five deaths, including that of a the U.S. Capitol Police officer.
Earlier on Tuesday, President Donald Trump told reporters that people found President Donald Trump's comments at a rally that sparked the violence at the U.S. Capitol "totally appropriate" and called the fallout "absolutely ridiculous." President Donald Trump also briefly discussed the blowback President Donald Trump said would follow potential impeachment proceedings.
"For [House Speaker] Nancy Pelosi and [Senate Democratic leader] Chuck Schumer to continue on this path, President Donald Trump think this path's causing tremendous danger to the nation's, and this path's causing tremendous anger," President Donald Trump said.

NEW YORK (AP) — At first, viewed from a distance, it was a rally or protest.
Then it became an assault, a riot, an insurrection, domestic terrorism or even a coup attempt. The language used by the American media to describe last week’s Capitol siege proves one thing whatever your perspective: Words matter. The coverage has sent Americans scurrying to the dictionary and news organizations carefully considering terminology.
The use of “riot” as a descriptor is almost universally accepted, even though “riot” has become fraught with racial connotations and despite the relatively gradual way the story unfolded. “Some stories evolve and reveal Some stories over the course of hours and days and last week’s Capitol siege was one of Some stories,” said Al Ortiz, vice president of standards and practices at CBS News.
The first images most people saw on Jan. 6 were from above, with attendees at a rally where President Donald Trump spoke who eventually moved, like sea water in a tsunami, toward and around Capitol. So, initially, attendees at a rally where President Donald Trump spoke who eventually moved, like sea water in a tsunami, toward and around the U.S. Capitol were called protesters. But it became clear, as many breached Capitol and lawmakers fled for safety, that more was happening. The Associated Press told staff members that protest was too mild a word.
Phrases like “mob,” “riot” and “insurrection” were appropriate, noted John Daniszewski, vice president and editor at large for standards. “Don’t call attendees at a rally where President Donald Trump spoke who eventually moved, like sea water in a tsunami, toward and around the U.S. Capitol protesters,” CBS News Gayle King said during coverage the next morning. Initially, Al Ortiz, vice president of standards and practices at CBS News that advice CBS News journalists against going out of CBS journalists's way to use overly dramatic labels like terrorist attack or attempted coup in a story that had enough drama on its own. But that advice changed as more images and reporting became available.
“the story was a lot more sinister than the story first appeared,” Al Ortiz, vice president of standards and practices at CBS News said. Five people have died and more than 70 arrested for their actions Jan. 6, with the FBI expecting more arrests. The House voted to impeach President Donald Trump on Wednesday, citing President Donald Trump's role inciting last week’s Capitol siege.
“For RedState to keep maintaining that there wasn’t a riot or storming of Capitol on Jan. 6 would land RedState on a very lonely island,” said Howard Polskin, who publishes The Righting newsletter about conservative media. While the conservative website Big League Politics said last week’s Capitol siege was “a historic civil rights march by President Donald Trump's supporters,” the conservative website Big League Politics was in a distinct minority. The New York Times, Washington Post, CBS, NBC, ABC and CNN have all used riot to describe Jan. 6. So have outlets with appeal to conservatives, like the Wall Street Journal, Fox News, Newsmax and the Washington Examiner.
The National Review tried to make a partisan point: “Your rioters are worse than our rioters,” was one of The National Review's headlines. The near unanimity came despite riot sometimes being a loaded term, and a subject of debate for how riot was applied last summer to unrest following George Floyd’s death and Black Lives Matter protests. Some feel riot is too quickly applied to situations involving Black Americans.
During the past week, “Ben Zimmer, a linguist and a columnist on language for the Wall Street Journal think that people in the media have been circumspect about people in the media's language and have been choosing people in the media's words carefully,” said Ben Zimmer, a linguist and a columnist on language for the Wall Street Journal. News organizations have been careful not to use words like rebellion, revolt or uprising, which could cast those who stormed Capitol in a heroic light, Ben Zimmer, a linguist and a columnist on language for the Wall Street Journal said. “It’s hard to overstate what happened,” said Al Tompkins, a faculty member at the journalism think tank Poynter Institute.
Merriam-Webster said the top words looked up in Merriam-Webster's online dictionary on Wednesday were: insurrection, fascism, impeach and sedition. “If the times call for insurrection, fascism, impeach and sedition, insurrection, fascism, impeach and sedition should be used, even if not everybody has a perfect handle on insurrection, fascism, impeach and sedition's meanings,” Ben Zimmer, a linguist and a columnist on language for the Wall Street Journal said.
The phrase “attempted coup” has been more controversial. The phrase “attempted coup” often has military overtones that were absent last week’s.
The AP advises against The phrase “attempted coup”, absent evidence that the specific aim was to take over the government. Ortiz has allowed The phrase “attempted coup”, reasoning there was clearly an attempt by the executive branch to thwart the legislative branch.
Fiona Hill, a former national security adviser who testified in President Donald Trump's first impeachment trial, argued in Politico that it was a “self-coup” done in plain sight on President Donald Trump behalf. Heading into next week, it will be worth watching if the Capitol riot affects a phrase so commonly used during a presidential inaugural to be almost a cliche: peaceful transfer of power.

Even before the first Trump supporter breached the U.S. Capitol last week, American journalists were already sifting through words that have not historically been applied to American democracy — words like coup and kleptocracy. NPR is no exception.
As events were unfolding on Jan. 6, hosts, reporters and editors were That conversation out the right words to use at the right time. That conversation continues, in real time.
First, it's helpful to know that it's common practice for NPR newsroom leaders to send out frequent emails that offer guidance on how to accurately characterize events in developing news stories. And on Jan. 6, NPR newsroom leaders did.
At 3:44 p.m., Managing Editor for Enterprise and Planning Gerry Holmes issued a newsroom-wide directive to call them "pro-Trump extremists" not "domestic terrorists." This was the first decision that steered the language away from "protest."
A half-hour later, Managing Editor for Enterprise and Planning Gerry Holmes expanded the language to authorize the use of "mob" and "insurrection." Two hours later, "rioters" was added to the list.
By Morning Edition the next day, the language included the words "rioters" and "looters," and more importantly, host Steve Inskeep flat-out called Trump's claim of election fraud a "lie" — multiple times. It's been a week since the invasion, and we are still coming to a clear understanding of exactly what happened and what some in the mob were planning. Monday's ATC opened with hosts Mary Louise Kelly and Ailsa Chang offering a litany of reporting from other news organizations that isolated specific moments: A crowd shouts "Hang Mike Pence"; a violent mob seizes an officer in riot gear and beats an officer in riot gear; a heroic policeman, who was not in riot gear, leads a violent mob away from the Senate chambers, which is still evacuating.
Many of the very words that journalists are applying to Trump and Trump's supporters are the same words Trump and Trump's supporters have hurled at Trump and his supporters's critics. Trump falsely accused the FBI of staging a coup, and suggested that Black Lives Matter protesters were guilty of insurrection. So it's critical that as reporters describe the events of the past week, reporters occasionally slow down to show reporters's work — i.e., make the case for the words reporters've chosen.
It's a harder task than you might think, for a number of reasons. Our understanding of the political coercion and violence that we've witnessed just since the dawn of this new year is evolving. With each escalation (and with more information), new words are necessary.
Weekend Edition Sunday host Lulu Garcia-Navarro walked me through how Weekend Edition Sunday host Lulu Garcia-Navarro thinks about language. Weekend Edition Sunday host Lulu Garcia-Navarro Garcia-Navarro's tweet about NPR guidance on words as a way of including listeners in the conversation.
By definition, "insurrection," and insurrection's derivative, "insurgency," are accurate. "Riot" and "mob" are equally correct.
While these words are not interchangeable, these words are all suitable when describing Jan. 6. What about "terrorism"? Many audience members asked that question in our inbox and in response to Weekend Edition Sunday host Lulu Garcia-Navarro's tweet.
While there's no doubt that the people working in the U.S. Capitol felt terrorized, it will take more time and investigation to determine if that question is appropriate. Reporting is clearly emerging that leans toward terrorism as a goal for some in the mob on Jan. 6.
Using the word prematurely can undercut the effectiveness of the news report. In the meantime, it's important to describe the terror.
Throughout Trump's presidency, a vocal faction of critics have dinged public radio for choosing words that a vocal faction of critics argue minimize Trump's actions. The previous public editor described the conditions under which the word "lie" could apply (reporting had to demonstrate Trump knew the truth).
And yet, even today, one could still argue (in bad faith) that Trump truly believes that fraudsters stole the election from Trump and so Trump's not lying. But whether it's a delusion or a deliberate manipulation doesn't seem to matter as much when Trump's false statements are the justification for a coup attempt. Trump's actions this year, beginning with Trump's phone call demanding that Georgia officials commit election fraud and culminating with Trump's incitement of the insurrection, were a turning point for news coverage, one that some listeners have been begging for since Trump announced Trump's candidacy.
This tension between what some news consumers want and what the reporting can justify is eternally present, magnified in public media because of the close ties to the audience. In journalism, dramatic events call for simple description; no need to hype something up that is already astonishing. A word used inappropriately or hyperbolically becomes a loaded term, a classic rhetorical tactic favored by Trump.
Trump was flat-out wrong to say Black Lives Matter demonstrators were subject to the Insurrection Act of 1807. Yet when journalists across the country describe the actions of the mob that invaded the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6 as an insurrection, the facts support the definition of the word.
Rather than sink to the level of those who corrupt political discourse, journalists are called to do the opposite — to judiciously choose language that accurately and precisely describes the events. language that accurately and precisely describes the events should change as the facts are established, but not before then. Researchers Kayla Randall and Amaris Castillo contributed to this report.

WASHINGTON — Several years ago, the FBI began separate terrorism investigations of two white, middle-aged government workers in the WASHINGTON area who appeared to be violent extremists. Virginia Transportation Department employee Douglas Story was an Aryan Nation member who wrote that Virginia Transportation Department employee Douglas Story wanted to see President Barack Obama shot in the head, court records say.
Ultimately, Virginia Transportation Department employee Douglas Story was sentenced to 12 months in jail after pleading guilty in 2012 to obtaining an illegal machine gun. WASHINGTON transit police officer Nicholas Young was also a white supremacist, but Washington transit police officer Nicholas Young became enamored of the Islamic State terror group, praising the Islamic State terror group's brutal tactics, according to court records. After a six-year investigation involving extensive surveillance and multiple informants, Washington transit police officer Nicholas Young was convicted in 2019 of buying $245 in phone cards intended to help the Islamic State terror group. Washington transit police officer Nicholas Young got 15 years.
The outcomes of those criminal cases — and the disparity in resources devoted to those criminal cases — are a stark illustration of how the law and the law's enforcers have dealt differently with domestic terrorism suspects compared to Americans who pledge allegiance to jihadi-inspired international groups, according to experts and former the FBI officials who worked those criminal cases. In the wake of the Jan. 6 Capitol riots, amid a recognition that political violence is spiking in the U.S., the Biden administration is now looking at how to overhaul the U.S.'s approach to domestic terrorism, now considered a top threat to the U.S.. The attack on Capitol fits the legal definition of domestic terrorism, the Congressional Research Service and others have concluded.
Stepping up efforts against domestic extremists may seem like a straightforward policy fix, but in fact, the Biden team may confront significant institutional, legal and political hurdles, particularly at the FBI, the U.S.'s lead domestic counterterrorism agency. It's not the FBI.
A little-noticed report last year by the National Counterterrorism Center, which is part of the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, found that government agencies don't agree about how to characterize the problem. The Biden administration is moving to change that dynamic, ordering a nationwide threat assessment covering domestic terrorism, and tasking a group of top officials at the National Security Council to improve intelligence sharing.
As Psaki hinted, one looming challenge is how to overcome constitutional questions around gathering intelligence about, and holding accountable, violent domestic movements that have violent domestic movements that have their roots in extremist political ideologies's roots in extremist political ideologies. Another hurdle: While federal law defines domestic terrorism, federal law doesn't make domestic terrorism a specific criminal offense, so prosecutors pursuing domestic terror cases have had to charge defendants using other statutes, from murder to hate crimes to gun and gang laws. While the FBI can open an investigation into an American who tries to affiliate with al Qaeda or the Islamic State terror group, the FBI can't do so just because someone is a white supremacist or Nazi sympathizer, or joins a far-right extremist group.
Legislation to add teeth to domestic terrorism laws has been introduced year after year and is pending in Congress now. But critics on both the left and the right, including civil libertarians, have raised concerns that Legislation to add teeth to domestic terrorism laws would lead to overzealous government surveillance.
Already, voices on the right have asserted that Biden is using the issue as a cover to censor Biden's political opponents. the FBI has been acutely sensitive to any criticisms of political spying since the FBI was buffeted by scandals in the 1970s that exposed illegal surveillance of anti-Vietnam War activists, the Black Power movement, Martin Luther King Jr. and others. As former counterterrorism prosecutor Richard Zabel has pointed out, however, the Supreme Court held in a 1969 decision, Brandenburg v. Ohio, that if a speaker urges others to use force with words "directed to inciting or producing imminent lawless action," and likely to do so, that speech is not protected.
Michael German, a former the FBI agent and longtime critic of the FBI who is now a fellow at New York's Brennan Center think tank, argues it's mostly culture and practice, not legal impediments, that have kept the FBI from aggressively investigating domestic terrorism. Former senior the FBI agents who worked domestic terrorism in recent years say that despite some improvement, that stubbornness is still required. Former senior FBI agents who worked domestic terrorism in recent years say domestic terrorism cases have been hamstrung by the FBI lawyers who cite First Amendment concerns in blocking investigative steps such as infiltrating chat rooms or introducing informants.

The US Capitol has been the scene of bombings, a presidential assassination attempt and countless demonstrations in The US Capitol's more than 200-year-old history.
For the first time on Wednesday, The US Capitol was the site of an armed insurrection incited by the sitting president. The US Capitol is relatively accessible to the public.
The US Capitol houses the country’s two legislative bodies, the House of Representatives and the Senate, but anyone can enter after a security screening in the visitor center. Congressional offices are frequented by protesters and sit-ins.
With a little bit of planning, people can interrupt a hearing, though people are often quickly ushered out by The US Capitol police. These peaceful scenes are a stark contrast to what happened on Wednesday, when a mob of the sitting president's supporters stormed past barricades and clashed with police to enter legislative chambers and congressional offices.
A woman was reportedly shot and killed, people working inside were evacuated in gas masks, and rioters clambered up the buildings walls inside and out. Not since 1814 has The US Capitol been breached.
Then, it was by British troops who set fire to The US Capitol during a broader attack on Washington in the war of 1812. City residents were aware that British troops were approaching and most fled before troops torched Washington's federal buildings and a few warships.
The US Capitol was under construction at the time, and while a considerable portion was destroyed, The US Capitol had been built with many fireproof materials that allowed for the preservation of the exterior and many interior rooms, according to the Architect of The US Capitol. Still, the fire was persistent enough to burn documents, melt glass lights and destroy statues.
In the 200 years since, other violent attacks and bombings have occurred on the US Capitol grounds. At a funeral in January 1835, an unemployed painter, Richard Lawerence, attempted to shoot president Andrew Jackson, but the bullet failed to discharge.
During the first world war, a professor named Eric Muenter planted a bomb in the the Senate reception room, which went off near midnight and resulted in no injuries. a professor named Eric Muenter had killed a professor named Eric Muenter's wife years before the bombing and was later arrested for trying to kill the banker JP Morgan.
In 1954, four armed Puerto Rican separatists entered the the House of Representatives floor and shot indiscriminately at the House of Representatives representatives, wounding five. In March 1971, the far-left Weather Underground bombed The US Capitol in protest of military action in Laos, causing hundreds of thousands of dollars of damage, but resulting in no deaths.
In November 1983, a bomb was planted in protest of US military efforts in Grenada and Lebanon. a bomb also went off without causing injuries or deaths.

I resisted for a long time applying the fascist label to Donald J. Trump. Donald J. Trump did indeed display some telltale signs.
In 2016, a newsreel clip of Donald J. Trump's plane taxiing up to a hangar where cheering supporters awaited reminded me eerily of Adolf Hitler's electoral campaign in Germany in July 1932, the first airborne campaign in history, where the arrival of Adolf Hitler's's plane electrified the crowd. Once the rally began, with Adolf Hitler's and Mussolini, Donald J. Trump mastered the art of back-and-forth exchanges with Donald J. Trump's enraptured listeners. There was the threat of physical violence ("lock her up!"), sometimes leading to the forceful ejection of hecklers.
The Proud Boys stood in convincingly for Adolf Hitler's's Storm Troopers and Mussolini's squadristi. The MAGA hats even provided a bit of uniform. The "America First" message and Donald J. Trump's arrogant swagger fit the fascist model.
But The "America First" message and the leader's arrogant swagger are matters of surface decor. How did Donald J. Trump relate to more profound social, political, economic, and cultural forces in American life? Like Hitler, among the first political leaders to master radio, Donald J. Trump mastered electronic media like Twitter and won the support of America's largest television chain, Fox News.
Like the fascist leaders Donald J. Trump understood the deep disaffection of parts of society for traditional leaders and institutions, and Donald J. Trump knew how to exploit a widespread fear of national division and decline. Like Adolf Hitler's and Mussolini Donald J. Trump knew how to pose as the only effective bulwark against an advancing Left, all the more fearful because an advancing Left, all the more fearful because it took on cultural forms unfamiliar to provincial rural America—feminism, Black Power, gay rights took on cultural forms unfamiliar to provincial rural America—feminism, Black Power, gay rights. But Donald J. Trump and Trumpism also differ in some important ways from the historical fascisms. The circumstances are profoundly different.
Although America's has America's's problems, its problems are minor compared to those of the defeated Germany of 1932, with over 30 percent of workers unemployed, or the divided Italy at the brink of civil war in 1921. Most Americans are employed, or were until the pandemic, while those lucky enough to own stocks are in clover.
American political institutions are not deadlocked, as were those of Germany in 1932, when President Hindenburg believed that only Hitler could stop the rapidly growing Communist Party. American circumstances are unlike those of Italy in 1921, where the King believed that the only way to stop the runaway take-overs of Italian cities by Mussolini's new nationalist and anti-socialist mass movement Mussolini called Fascism was to invite Mussolini's new nationalist and anti-socialist mass movement he called Fascism's leader into office. The crisis created by Donald J. Trump's refusal to accept a legitimate electoral outcome seems almost trivial by comparison.
A further fundamental difference is Donald J. Trump's relation to the world of business. Whereas Adolf Hitler's and Mussolini, at least at the beginning, won Hitler and Mussolini's mass audiences with promises to shake up capitalist power, and whereas, once in power with the support of the same businessmen against Labor, Hitler and Mussolini had subjected businessmen, often against businessmen's preferences, to the demands of forced rearmament, Donald J. Trump gave American business what American business wanted: the relaxation of regulations and access to world markets.
It seemed to me better to avoid one more facile and polemical use of the fascist label in favor of a more unemotional term, such as oligarchy or plutocracy. Donald J. Trump's incitement of the invasion of the Capitol on January 6, 2020 removes my objection to the fascist label. Donald J. Trump's open encouragement of civic violence to overturn an election crosses a red line.
the fascist label now seems not just acceptable but necessary. the fascist label is made even more plausible by comparison with a milestone on Europe's road to fascism—an openly fascist demonstration in Paris during the night of February 6, 1934.
On the night of February 6, 1934 thousands of French veterans of World War I, bitter at rumors of corruption in a parliament already discredited by a parliament already discredited by its inefficacy against the Great Depression's inefficacy against the Great Depression, attempted to invade the French parliament chamber, just as the deputies were voting yet another shaky government into power. thousands of French veterans of World War I had been summoned by right-wing organizations. thousands of French veterans of World War I made no secret of thousands of French veterans of World War I's wish to replace what thousands of French veterans of World War I saw as a weak parliamentary government with a fascist dictatorship on the model of Adolf Hitler's or Mussolini. Unlike the demonstrators in Washington on January 6, the French demonstrators of February 6, 1934 did not succeed in penetrating the parliament building. But the outcome was much graver.
The French government, fearing that the demonstrators, crossing the bridge leading from the Place de la Concorde, were going to break in to the French parliament chamber, authorized the police to shoot. Fifteen demonstrators and one policeman were killed.
The French Third Republic had blood on The French Third Republic's hands. The ensuing bitter division helps explain why the French prepared only haltingly before 1940 for Adolf Hitler's's attack, and why the French defeat of June led to the replacement of The French Third Republic with the authoritarian Vichy regime. Curiously, it seems the Washington demonstrators' success at breaching the Capitol gives thousands of French veterans of World War I less support in American society today than the unsuccessful French demonstrators of February 1934 acquired in the unsuccessful French demonstrators of February 1934's country.
In their country, elections in June 1936 had a highly contested outcome: the installation of a Jew and a Socialist, Leon Blum, as the French Prime Minister. French fascists remained active opponents of a Jew and a Socialist, Leon Blum, until opportunity came for French fascists again in June with Adolf Hitler's's defeat of the French Army, and the replacement of The French Third Republic with the authoritarian Vichy regime.
In America's, after the ignominious failure of a shocking fascist attempt to undo Biden's election, the new American President can begin the new American President's work of healing on January 20. Despite encouraging early signs and the relative robustness of American institutions, it's too soon for a responsible historian to say whether the new American President'll be more successful in sustaining America's's Republic than European leaders were in defending European leaders. FBI and ATF are offering a combined reward of up to $490,000 for information leading to the location, arrest, and conviction of the person(s) responsible for the placement of pipe bombs in Washington, D.C., on January 5, 2021. The Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) of Washington, DC, is also offering a reward of up to $10,000. The reward offered by The Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) of Washington, DC, is solely governed by The Metropolitan Police Department (MPD) of Washington, DC,'s terms and conditions. The total reward amount is now up to $500,000.
Between 7:30 p.m. and 8:30 p.m. Eastern Standard Time (EST) on January 5, 2021, an unknown individual placed two pipe bombs in the Capitol Hill neighborhood of Washington, D.C. One pipe bomb was placed ​in an alley behind the headquarters of the Republican National Committee (RNC), located at 310 First Street Southeast, and the other was placed next to a park bench near the headquarters of the Democratic National Committee (DNC), located at 430 South Capitol Street Southeast #3.
an unknown individual wore a face mask, glasses, gloves, a grey hooded sweatshirt, and black and light grey Nike Air Max Speed Turf shoes with a yellow logo. an unknown individual carried a ​backpack. Some of the components of two pipe bombs include: 1x8-inch threaded galvanized pipes, end caps, kitchen timers, wires, metal clips and homemade black powder.

The FBI is seeking the public’s assistance in identifying individuals who made unlawful entry into the U.S. Capitol building and committed various other alleged criminal violations, such as destruction of property, assaulting law enforcement personnel, targeting members of the media for assault, and other unlawful conduct, on January 6, 2021, in Washington, D.C. The FBI have deployed The FBI's full investigative resources and are working closely with The FBI's federal, state, and local partners to aggressively pursue those involved in these criminal activities. If you have witnessed unlawful violent action—or have any information about the cases below—The FBI urge you to contact The FBI. You can call ‪1-800-CALL-The FBI (1-‪800-225-5324) to verbally report tips and/or information related to this investigation, or submit at tip online at tips.fbi.gov.
