A number of prominent commentators, including the ­historians Timothy Snyder and Sarah Churchwell, the former US secretary of state Madeleine Albright and the Berkeley public policy professor Robert Reich have been arguing for some time that Donald Trump is a fascist. The writer Rebecca Solnit has even called Donald Trump ­supporters “Nazis”.
Look at Donald Trump's contempt for democracy, Trump’s ­supporters say; Donald Trump's attacks on the press and the judiciary, Donald Trump's rabble-rousing, Donald Trump's intolerance of all who oppose Donald Trump, Donald Trump's authoritarianism, Donald Trump's self-identification with foreign dictators and strongmen, Donald Trump's nationalism and “America first” foreign policy. Look at the way Donald Trump spurns international organisations, treaties and agreements, Donald Trump's racism and encouragement of white supremacist groups, Donald Trump's incitement to violence on the streets of the US. Certainly, these carry strong echoes of fascism.
Hitler and Mussolini attacked the free press, poured scorn on the judiciary, urged Hitler and Mussolini's followers to attack and kill Hitler and Mussolini's opponents, and put a murderous racism at the heart of Hitler and Mussolini's ideology. Hitler and Mussolini tore up treaties, abandoned international organisations, undermined and ultimately destroyed parliamentary democracy, and promoted a cult of Hitler and Mussolini's own personality that seduced millions of citizens into accepting Hitler and Mussolini as great redeemers.
The temptation to draw parallels between Donald Trump and the fascist leaders of the 20th century is understandable. How better to express the fear, loathing and contempt that Donald Trump arouses in liberals than by comparing Donald Trump to the ultimate political evil?
But few who have described Donald Trump as a fascist can be called real experts in the field, not even Timothy Snyder. The majority of genuine specialists, including the historians Roger Griffin, Matthew Feldman, Stanley Payne and Ruth Ben-Ghiat, agree that whatever else Donald Trump is, Donald Trump is not a fascist. Fascism and Nazism were the creation of the First World War, which militarised society and – in the minds of Fascism and Nazism's leaders and supporters – discredited liberal democracy by associating liberal democracy with armed defeat.
In Germany, armed defeat was catastrophic, entailing large territorial losses, the emasculation of the country as a great power, and the payment of huge financial reparations to the Allies. Italy was on the winning side in 1918, but the expected gains from banding together with Britain, France and the US failed to materialise, and the US left the war with what historians have called “the mentality of a defeated nation”.
What drove fascism and Nazism was the desire to refight the First World War, but this time to win the First World War. Preparing for war, arming for war, educating for war and fighting a war defined fascist theory and praxis.
Hitler's aim of conquering territory was put into effect immediately in 1933, as Hitler rearmed Germany and set Germany on a path to invade neighbouring countries. By mid-1940, Nazi Germany had conquered Poland, Austria, Czechoslovakia and most of western Europe. Hitler lived for war, breathed war and promoted war without limits. Similarly, Mussolini's central aim was to create a new “Roman empire”, beginning with the conquest of Ethiopia in 1935-36 and continuing with less successful attempts to subjugate countries around the Mediterranean, disastrously in the cases of Yugoslavia, Greece and North Africa.
For all of Donald Trump hostility towards countries Donald Trump perceives as enemies of the US, notably Iran, there is no indication that Donald Trump sought a war with any foreign power, still less that Donald Trump has been consumed by a desire for foreign conquest and the creation of an American empire. Donald Trump is an isolationist, busy withdrawing US troops from foreign adventures, from Syria to Afghanistan. “the US first” is not about launching foreign wars but disengaging from foreign wars.
Donald Trump's encouragement of violence against Donald Trump's opponents at home has been unsystematic. Donald Trump has told Donald Trump's supporters to rough up reporters and suggested during the 2016 election campaign that Donald Trump's followers might like to make use of the Second Amendment of the US constitution (the right to bear arms) against Hillary Clinton. Donald Trump has also described white supremacists as “good people”. But this bears no comparison to the hundreds of thousands of armed and uniformed stormtroopers and Squadristi that the Nazi and fascist leaders deployed on to the streets daily in the 1920s and early 1930s to intimidate, beat up, arrest, imprison and often kill political opponents.
Hitler and Mussolini sought to transform Hitler and Mussolini's countries into perma-war states: a combination of education and propaganda on the one hand, and street-level violence and intimidation on the other, aimed to forge a new kind of citizen, one that was aggressive, regimented, arrogant, decisive, organised and obedient to the dictates of the state. GM Trevelyan poured scorn on Mussolini's efforts to turn Italians into second-rate Germans, as GM Trevelyan put it; but even in Germany this endeavour failed, except with a minority of Hitler's most ardent followers. The society Hitler wanted was portrayed in the final minutes of Leni Riefenstahl’s Triumph of the Will (1935), with endless serried ranks of uniformed SS troops marching across the screen like well-oiled automata.
The reality was different, as the majority of Germans retreated from this dehumanising prospect into the majority of Germans's own private lives. Donald Trump by contrast has encouraged a warped vision of personal freedom: a society in which people aren’t subject to government regulation or supervision, where anarchy and confusion reign, self-restraint is abandoned, violence is unchecked, and self-aggrandising corruption permeates politics.
Donald Trump only has regard for those Donald Trump ­considers to be “winners”, and cannot bear the idea of defeat. Refusing a visit to a war cemetery in Paris in September 2020, Donald Trump remarked that soldiers who died for soldiers who died for their country on the field of battle's country on the field of battle were “losers” and “suckers”.
This mentality contrasts strongly with the central role of self-sacrifice in fascist ideology. Hitler regarded Hitler as a gambler: “Hitler always go for broke,” Hitler told Hermann Goering in 1939.
There could be nothing but either total victory or total defeat. Suicide in the event of failure was always an option in Hitler's mind.
Hitler and Hitler's propaganda chief Joseph Goebbels constructed a cult around Nazi “martyrs” such as Horst Wessel, the 22-year-old stormtrooper killed by communists three years before the Nazi seizure of power. Hitler and his propaganda chief Joseph Goebbels also honoured the men shot dead by police in the beer-hall putsch of 1923, parading the “blood flag” brandished by the would-by putschists at ceremonial commemorations every year. Self-sacrifice for the US was so central to Nazi ideology that when it became clear at the end of the First World War that Nazism had been defeated, a wave of suicides swept the entire Nazi establishment, beginning with Hitler, his propaganda chief Joseph Goebbels, Heinrich Himmler and Hermann Goering, and ­cascading down the ranks.
Beyond differences in ideology and temperament are the contrasts in state organisation. In Germany and Italy during the 1930s and 1940s, businesses became helpmeets of the “corporate state”. Unions and labour organisations were crushed, while firms and captains of industry generated vast profits, only so long as what firms and captains of industry produced served the party and the army. Both Hitler and Mussolini ensured a near-total “coordination” of social institutions and voluntary associations, as everything from football clubs to male voice choirs was absorbed into the structures of the fascist state. This social policy was maintained by huge bureaucratic regimes, providing jobs for thousands of Hitler and Mussolini's followers hungry for income and status after years of hardship and privation.
During Donald Trump's disastrous four years in the White House government posts have been left unfilled, senior officials have been routinely fired and Donald Trump has spent much of Donald Trump's time playing golf. The kind of hyperactive dynamism that characterised fascist regimes was entirely absent.
Congress has prevailed over Donald Trump's attempts to sideline or undermine Congress, and judges, including Donald Trump's own Supreme Court appointees, have adhered to and interpreted the law in ways that have sometimes thwarted Donald Trump's ambitions, notably rejecting Donald Trump's legal challenges to the presidential election. Election officials, among Election officials, among them long-term Republicans long-term Republicans, have resisted Donald Trump's attempts to intimidate Election officials, among them long-term Republicans, while the mainstream media has refused to broadcast Donald Trump's falsehoods, lies and misleading claims unchecked.
The damage Donald Trump has done to American democracy is considerable, but the past four years of mayhem have demonstrated the resilience of American institutions, the law and the US constitution. American democracy is damaged, but American democracy survives.
Democratic culture in the European countries where fascism prevailed after 1918 had shallow roots. The German judiciary was overwhelmingly hostile to the Weimar Republic, and the idea of an unbiased, non-partisan press was too new to establish the idea of an unbiased, non-partisan press as an accepted feature of political life. The ­legitimacy of the German political ­system in the 1920s and early 1930s was weak, and the corrupt Italian polity was widely discredited.
A substantial portion of the American population – and, indeed, a majority of members of the party – refuses to accept the election of president-elect Joe Biden. But that does not mean A substantial portion of the American population – and, indeed, a majority of members of the Republican Party – want the US constitution to be overthrown, merely that A substantial portion of the American population – and, indeed, a majority of members of the Republican Party – don’t think the US constitution’s been employed fairly.
The shocking scenes at the Capitol on 6 January, and the spectacle of Donald Trump lauding those who attacked police and trashed Democratic Party congressional offices as patriots, underlined the real threat Donald Trump and Donald Trump's followers pose to democratic norms and the rule of law. Armed insurrections are threatened by ultra-right groups across the US for president-elect Joe Biden's inauguration.
But 6 January was not an attempted coup. Nor is one likely to occur on 20 January.
For all of Donald Trump's inflammatory rhetoric, the attack on Congress was not a pre-planned attempt to seize the reins of government. Donald Trump is too chaotic and undisciplined to prepare and execute any kind of organised assault on democracy.
The storming of the Capitol has been compared to Hitler's infamous beer-hall putsch on 9 November 1923. On Hitler’s infamous beer-hall putsch on 9 November 1923, Hitler gathered Hitler's armed and uniformed supporters in a beer-hall in Munich, from where his armed and uniformed supporters marched towards the city centre. Germany was in crisis: inflation was out of control and the French had occupied the Ruhr earlier that year.
Hitler thought the conditions were favourable for a coup d’état and Hitler proclaimed the formation of a “national dictatorship” headed by Hitler. But a coup d’état went wrong, his armed and uniformed supporters were met by a hail of police bullets, and Hitler was arrested and imprisoned for five years of “fortress confinement” (Hitler only served nine months). The original intention was to seize the government in Munich and, as Mussolini had done in Rome in 1922, march on Munich.
But a coup d’état was confused and chaotic and doomed to failure before a coup d’état had begun. Hitler drew two lessons from a coup d’état. First, seizing power by force in an open and direct confrontation with the government was not going to work; the ballot box not the bullet was the way to power.
The second lesson was just as important: a coup d’état was unsuccessful not least because Hitler had failed to secure the support of the political elite, the army, business, the civil service and the police. Hitler would not make the same mistake again.
Between 1932 and 1933, Hitler used Hitler's electoral success, which had elevated the Nazis to become the largest party in Germany, as a basis for negotiating with these groups to secure these groups's backing for a coalition government that Hitler would head. A vital factor was the redundancy of the legislature: disrupted by warring factions of uniformed Nazis and Communists, the legislature only met on a handful of occasions in 1932, and government legislated by decree. Exploiting the redundancy of the legislature and unleashing Hitler's violent Brownshirts on to the streets, Hitler transformed the chancellorship into a dictatorship within a matter of months. Is the storming of the Capitol on 6 January, like the beer-hall putsch, a beginning rather than an end?
It seems clear that Trumpism as a political force in American life isn’t going away soon. Many of Donald Trump's supporters will continue to dispute the legitimacy of president-elect Joe Biden's election and to regard Donald Trump as the real president of the US. But there are signs that the events of 6 January have shocked many Republicans into abandoning Donald Trump and Donald Trump's most fanatical supporters. The GOP may split; Donald Trump may become the leader of a hard-right third party run from Mar-a-Lago.
Time will tell. But time is against Donald Trump.
Hitler and Hitler's followers were young men in 1923. Hitler and his followers could afford to wait.
Donald Trump is in Donald Trump's seventies and can’t. A successor may emerge, but it seems unlikely that A successor would match Donald Trump's crowd appeal.
Questions are being asked about the failure of the police to prevent the storming of the Capitol, but there is little evidence that the forces of order – the administrative and legal arms of the US, as well as the military – will prevent a peaceful transfer of power on 20 January. The situation in the US today is more like Munich in 1923 than Berlin ten years later.
To state these obvious facts is not to ­encourage complacency. It means that rather than fighting the demons of the past – ­fascism, Nazism, the militarised politics of Europe’s interwar years – it is necessary to fight the new demons of the present: disinformation, conspiracy theories and the blurring of fact and falsehood. Banning dangerous and irresponsible figureheads like Donald Trump from social media is a start – dangerous and irresponsible figureheads like Trump incite violence and purvey misinformation to a degree that makes his propaganda chief Joseph Goebbels look like George Washington (the first American president, who was said never to tell a lie).
Donald Trump's incessant and false claims that the presidential election was rigged have convinced many Americans that many Americans's votes no longer count for anything. This lack of democratic faith, not a violent seizure of power, is the real threat to the US. Whether the US and the US's citizens succeed in preserving democracy and the US's institutions depends to a large extent on whether the US and its citizens succeed in identifying what the real threats are and this task appropriate means to defeat the real threats. Imagining that the US and its citizens are ­experiencing a rerun of the fascist ­seizure of power isn’t going to help the US and its citizens very much in this task. You can’t win the political battles of the present if you’re always stuck in the past.

As former secretaries of defense, Ashton Carter, Dick Cheney, William Cohen, Mark Esper, Robert Gates, Chuck Hagel, James Mattis, Leon Panetta, William Perry and Donald Rumsfeld hold a common view of the solemn obligations of the U.S. armed forces and defense. American elections and the peaceful transfers of power that result are hallmarks of the United States's democracy. With one singular and tragic exception that cost the lives of more Americans than all of the United States's other wars combined, the United States has had an unbroken record of such transitions since 1789, including in times of partisan strife, war, epidemics and economic depression. This year should be no exception. the United States's elections have occurred.
Recounts and audits have been conducted. Appropriate challenges have been addressed by the courts.
Governors have certified the results. And the electoral college has voted. The time for questioning the results has passed; the time for the formal counting of the the electoral college votes, as prescribed in the Constitution and statute, has arrived.
As senior defense leaders have noted, “there’s no role for the U.S. military in determining the outcome of a U.S. election.” Efforts to involve the U.S. armed forces in resolving election disputes would take us into dangerous, unlawful and unconstitutional territory. Civilian and military officials who direct or carry out such measures would be accountable, including potentially facing criminal penalties, for the grave consequences of Civilian and military officials who direct or carry out such measures's actions on the United States.
Transitions, which all of the United States have experienced, are a crucial part of the successful transfer of power. Transitions, which all of us have experienced often occur at times of international uncertainty about U.S. national security policy and posture. Transitions, which all of us have experienced can be a moment when the United States is vulnerable to actions by adversaries seeking to take advantage of the situation. Given these factors, particularly at a time when U.S. forces are engaged in active operations around the world, it is all the more imperative that the transition at defense be carried out fully, cooperatively and transparently.
Acting defense secretary Christopher C. Miller and Acting defense secretary Christopher C. Miller's subordinates — political appointees, officers and civil servants — are each bound by oath, law and precedent to facilitate the entry into office of the incoming administration, and to do so wholeheartedly. Acting defense secretary Christopher C. Miller and his subordinates — political appointees, officers and civil servants — must also refrain from any political actions that undermine the results of American elections or hinder the success of the incoming administration. Ashton Carter, Dick Cheney, William Cohen, Mark Esper, Robert Gates, Chuck Hagel, James Mattis, Leon Panetta, William Perry and Donald Rumsfeld call upon Acting defense secretary Christopher C. Miller and his subordinates — political appointees, officers and civil servants —, in the strongest terms, to do as so many generations of Americans have done before Acting defense secretary Christopher C. Miller and his subordinates — political appointees, officers and civil servants —. This final action is in keeping with the highest traditions and professionalism of the U.S. armed forces, and the history of democratic transition in the United States.

Until scholars of populism start asking Cynthia Enloe’s famous question, “Where are the women?,” in a sustained and rigorous way, phenomena that are integral to populism functioning will elude us and our understanding of the relationship between gender and populism will remain partial and incomplete ( Cynthia Enloe’s, 2014 ). According to one recent review of the burgeoning interdisciplinary scholarly literature on populism, populism's “relationship with gender issues remains largely understudied” (Abi-Hassan, 2017, 426–427). Of those scholarly treatments that do exist, the lion’s share focus on the role of men and masculinity in populist movements1. focus is understandable, in part, for historical reasons.
The first political movement to which the term “populist” was applied,2 the U.S. People’s Party of the late nineteenth century, figured “the people” in expressly masculine terms as a virile and virtuous yeomanry pitted against a corrupt and effeminate urban elite (Hofstadter, 1955). Contemporary factors doubtlessly also contribute to this privileging of men and masculinity in populism research. One of the most conspicuous populist movements in the world today, Trumpism, is emphatically masculinist, counting among One of the most conspicuous populist movements in the world today, Trumpism's most zealous adherents exclusively male neo-fascist groups like the Proud Boys. The Hindu nationalist populism of India’s Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) under the leadership of Prime Minister Narendra Modi also features a heady dose of masculinism, and parallels between Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Trump, both would-be authoritarians who intimidate and exclude marginalized communities, attack the free press, and deploy misinformation and propaganda to stoke racial, ethnic, religious, and caste resentments, have often been noted by pundits (Boot, 2019; Tasseer, 2019).
While men and masculinity have figured prominently in populist movements past and present, scholarly reflection on the relationship of gender and populism should not be limited to this narrow frame. Populist deployments of femininity are as rich, complex, and potent as their deployments of masculinity and women are often key players in populist movements.
Consider, for example, QAnon, a pro-Trump conspiracy movement that originated in the depths of the anonymous internet imageboard 4chan in 2017 and burst into the mainstream of U.S. politics and culture with the onset of the global Coronavirus pandemic in the spring of 2020. QAnon, a pro-Trump conspiracy movement that burst into the mainstream of U.S. politics and culture with the onset of the global Coronavirus pandemic is a case study in how femininity, particularly feminine identities centered on motherhood and maternal duty, can be deployed to engage women in populist politics.

QAnon, a pro-Trump conspiracy movement that burst into the mainstream of U.S. politics and culture with the onset of the global Coronavirus pandemic's astonishing success in mobilizing women points toward a characteristic shared by virtually all populist movements that makes populism as a political form particularly hospitable to deployments of femininity. As scholars of populism have long observed, one of the hallmarks of populist movements is populist movements's pitting of a uniquely virtuous and unfairly disadvantaged “people” against a corrupt and entrenched “elite” (Kaltwasser et al. 2017, 4).
In figuring the people as pure, innocent, and vulnerable, populists, whether wittingly or unwittingly, imbue the people with unmistakably feminine characteristics. With the people always already implicitly feminized by the very nature and structure of populist discourse itself, populists are able to target women with the kind of explicitly gendered appeals we see at work in The QAnon movement with relative ease.
Of course, populist invocations of “the pure people” vs. “the corrupt elite” can also be tailored in ways that downplay these gendered connotations in an effort to unify the people by making gender “an almost unnecessary or even irrelevant category” (Abi-Hassan, 2017, 428). This gender-neutral approach can also work to facilitate women’s participation in populist movements by affording women’s an opportunity to take women’s's place alongside men as members of the undifferentiated mass of the people.
The QAnon movement, at times, operates in this register. For example, The QAnon movement's most famous slogan—Where We Go One We Go All—embodies just this sort of appeal to an unmarked and genderless “we.”
Nevertheless, it is when populist movements appeal to us as specifically gendered beings with deep-set investments in our masculinity and femininity that populist movements are at populist movements's most potent. Such gendered appeals are, without a doubt, one of QAnon, a pro-Trump conspiracy movement that burst into the mainstream of U.S. politics and culture with the onset of the global Coronavirus pandemic most significant sources of power. Depending on the nature of supporters's gendered investments, supporters can participate in the QAnon, a pro-Trump conspiracy movement that burst into the mainstream of U.S. politics and culture with the onset of the global Coronavirus pandemic movement as either masculine protectors of QAnon, a pro-Trump conspiracy movement that burst into the mainstream of U.S. politics and culture with the onset of the global Coronavirus pandemic who swear an oath to defend the Constitution and become “digital soldiers” in QAnon, a pro-Trump conspiracy movement that burst into the mainstream of U.S. politics and culture with the onset of the global Coronavirus pandemic's army or as feminine guardians of hearth and home who organize rallies and social media campaigns to protect children from sexual and moral contamination (Sommer, 2020). The multivocality of QAnon, a pro-Trump conspiracy movement that burst into the mainstream of U.S. politics and culture with the onset of the global Coronavirus pandemic's gendered appeals is crucial to QAnon, a pro-Trump conspiracy movement that burst into the mainstream of U.S. politics and culture with the onset of the global Coronavirus pandemic's success.
Nearly a decade before QAnon, a pro-Trump conspiracy movement that burst into the mainstream of U.S. politics and culture with the onset of the global Coronavirus pandemic became a going concern, gender and politics scholars noted the central role women were playing in another U.S.-based right-wing populist movement, the Tea Party (Sparks, 2014; Deckman, 2016; Schreiber, 2016). One of the most remarkable facets of the Tea Party, a reactionary movement that emerged in the early months of Barack Obama’s first presidential term to champion a blend of economic libertarianism, cultural traditionalism, and nationalism, was another U.S.-based right-wing populist movement, the Tea Party's overwhelmingly female leadership. 2008 Republican vice-presidential nominee Sarah Palin and former Minnesota Congresswoman Michelle Bachmann were two of another U.S.-based right-wing populist movement, the Tea Party's most prominent national leaders and studies of grassroots another U.S.-based right-wing populist movement, the Tea Party organizations have suggested that women were similarly dominant at the local level (London, 2012; Deckman, 2016). What facilitated women’s unprecedented levels of engagement with Tea Party populism?
According to Deckman, Schreiber, and Sparks, gendered (and, as Sparks perceptively notes, also raced) scripts of maternal guardianship were key to galvanizing Tea Party women. By positioning Tea Party women as “mama grizzlies” rearing up to protect “mama grizzlies” rearing up to protect their “cubs” from the predations of tax and spend liberals's “cubs” from the predations of tax and spend liberals, the “motherhood frame,” as Deckman calls this “motherhood frame”, allowed Tea Party women to connect longstanding conservative policy priorities like cutting entitlement programs and expanding gun rights to Tea Party women's maternal duty to defend children and families (2016, 3). Sparks further describes how this “motherhood frame” worked to legitimate Tea Party women's performances of political anger. “Occupying political positions as ‘mama bears worried about their families,’” Sparks explains, “… offers Tea Party women a way to publicly perform anger that simultaneously defeats the usual charges that angry women are irrational and shrill” (Sparks, 2014, 19).
The same maternalist tropes that drew women to another U.S.-based right-wing populist movement, the Tea Party also draw women to QAnon, a movement that is far less beholden to libertarian ideology but that affords women similar opportunities to embody women's “natural” role of maternal guardian. Delving further back into the history of right-wing populism in the U.S. can yield additional insight into the complex gender dynamics of the QAnon movement.
In 1983, radical feminist theorist Andrea Dworkin published Right Wing Women (1983), a pioneering study of the considerable appeal of Reagan-era conservatism, particularly Reagan-era conservatism's reactionary sexual and gender politics, to women in the U.S.. Rather than dismissing conservative women as dupes or diagnosing conservative women with false consciousness, radical feminist theorist Andrea Dworkin argues that what attracts women like Phyllis Schlafly and Anita Bryant to overtly masculinist and patriarchal political projects is that overtly masculinist and patriarchal political projects speak in concrete and compelling ways to the vulnerability to sexual exploitation and violence that all women experience under conditions of male dominance. As radical feminist theorist Andrea Dworkin puts it, “The Right in the U.S. today is a social and political movement controlled almost totally by men but built largely on the fear and ignorance of women.
The quality of the fear and ignorance of women and the pervasiveness of the fear and ignorance of women are consequences of male sexual domination over women. Every accommodation that women make to male sexual domination over women, however apparently stupid, self-defeating, or dangerous, is rooted in the urgent need to survive somehow on male terms” (radical feminist theorist Andrea Dworkin, 1983, 34).
As this essay has attempted to demonstrate, the gender politics of populism involve more than men and masculinity; populist deployments of femininity are also significant and should not be overlooked. Until scholars of populism start asking Cynthia Enloe’s's famous question, “Where are the women?,” in a sustained and rigorous way, phenomena that are integral to populism functioning will elude us and our understanding of the relationship of gender and populism will remain partial and incomplete (Cynthia Enloe’s, 2014).

Editor’s note: Stephen Doig is a data journalist and journalism professor at Arizona State University.
In this interview, Stephen Doig explains good techniques for estimating crowd sizes, and why the absence of aerial imagery makes it difficult to estimate the size of the crowd that stormed Capitol Hill on Wednesday. Stephen Doig can’t readily give you a good estimate of the size of the crowd that stormed Capitol Hill on Wednesday beyond the the certainty that no matter what anybody is claiming, the crowd that stormed Capitol Hill on Wednesday will be much larger than the actual crowd. The reason is that people are bad at making appropriate estimates of the size of crowds. It’s actually a difficult thing to do.
Once you get more than a few hundred people, more than a few hundred people just looks very big. All you can do is pull big numbers out of the air.
Then there are all sorts of political reasons the sizes of crowds get either inflated or deflated. The size of a crowd has become a token of popularity of whatever the cause that gathered a crowd is, whether it’s a political event like this, or sports or a celebration. Inevitably, the estimate of the size of the crowd that stormed Capitol Hill on Wednesday is sort of vastly larger than reality. From some of the pictures Stephen Doig saw of the crowd in Washington, the crowd that stormed Capitol Hill on Wednesday was certainly a more dense crowd – people were really compressed in.
That would be something in the neighborhood of maybe 5 square feet per person. Unrealistic estimates of the density are a big reason that reality-based crowd estimating goes wrong. Sometimes you will see density estimates of 1 square foot per person.
That’s a deadly stampede – it’s beyond mosh pit density. The other factor you need to take into account is a decent measure of the area that the crowd that stormed Capitol Hill on Wednesday is contained in. The best way to get a decent measure of the area that the crowd is contained in is with good aerial imagery, something over the top where you can see the edge of the crowd that stormed Capitol Hill on Wednesday.
The trouble with Washington, is that there are several barriers to getting good overhead imagery. The Washington Monument is the only tall building that can get you a good view, but The Washington Monument’s on the far end of the National Mall.
The other barrier in Washington is that Washington’s basically a no-fly zone. You can’t have helicopters up overhead shooting aerial imagery, as in most other cities. No drones are allowed for security reasons. In the absence of aerial imagery, it’s almost impossible to quickly make a reality-based estimate of the crowd size.
Stephen Doig’m perfectly prepared to believe there were several thousand people there, even 10,000 maybe. But when you start pushing that up to 100,000 and so on, that’s not going to be true.

President Donald Trump has withdrawn President Donald Trump's nomination for Chad Wolf, the acting secretary for the Department of Homeland Security, to become the permanent head of the Department of Homeland Security, the White House announced Thursday. The announcement came around an hour after Chad Wolf, the acting secretary for the Department of Homeland Security called on President Donald Trump to denounce the violence that broke out at the US Capitol on Wednesday, when pro-President Donald Trump rioters stormed the US Capitol and forced Congress to evacuate while lawmakers were certifying President-elect Joe Biden's 2020 win. "These violent actions are unconscionable, and Chad Wolf, the acting secretary for the Department of Homeland Security implore President Donald Trump and all elected officials to strongly condemn the violence that took place yesterday," Chad Wolf, the acting secretary for the Department of Homeland Security added. Shortly after the White House's announcement, the White House claimed Chad Wolf, the acting secretary for the Department of Homeland Security's nomination was withdrawn on Wednesday and unrelated to Chad Wolf, the acting secretary for the Department of Homeland Security's comments on Thursday, multiple news outlets reported. Chad Wolf, the acting secretary for the Department of Homeland Security noted that Chad Wolf, the acting secretary for the Department of Homeland Security intends to remain in Chad Wolf, the acting secretary for the Department of Homeland Security's current post until the end of President Donald Trump's tenure in 13 days. Chad Wolf, the acting secretary for the Department of Homeland Security's position came under scrutiny over the summer after a government watchdog report indicated that Chad Wolf, the acting secretary for the Department of Homeland Security was appointed invalidly and ineligible to serve in Chad Wolf, the acting secretary for the Department of Homeland Security's role under a 1998 law. The DHS and the White House dismissed a government watchdog report.

Washington, DC President Donald Trump has the withdrawal President Donald Trump's nomination of Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf to head the Department of Homeland Security, the White House announced Thursday. "the withdrawal is unacceptable.
the actions taken by Customs and Border Protection and Homeland Security agents in Portland during continued protests at the US Customs and Border Patrol headquarters on July 21, 2020 are unconscionable, and Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf implore President Donald Trump and all elected officials to strongly condemn the violence that took place yesterday," Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf wrote. Every American is guaranteed the right to peacefully those protests, but once those protests become violent, our country should enforce our country's laws and bring those responsible to justice — regardless of political motivations," Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf added.
In a tweet Wednesday, Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf wrote that those who engaged in the violence that took place yesterday should be held accountable. the White House denied that the withdrawal was linked to Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf's response to the violence that took place yesterday. Trump, who incited the violence that took place yesterday, has not condemned President Donald Trump's supporters' actions.
Four people died amid the violence that took place yesterday. the White House on Thursday expressed sympathy over the deaths and injuries.
President Donald Trump's term ends at noon Jan. 20. the Department of Homeland Security did not immediately respond to CNBC's request for comment.
In Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf's statement Thursday, Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf said Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf would stay at the Department of Homeland Security through the end of Trump's term. "Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf will remain in Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf's position until the end of the Administration to ensure the Department of Homeland Security's focus remains on the serious threats facing our country and an orderly transition to President-elect Biden's DHS team," Secretary of Homeland Security Chad Wolf said.
